Researchers in the Department of Anesthesia and Perioperative Medicine at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) have found that an FDA-approved drug may help to decrease pain after surgery. In the pilot study published in Pain Management
column10: the Jerry G. Reves Endowed Chair in Basic Science Anesthesiology Research and a senior author of the published study. Scofield has conducted laboratory research on NAC
column11: an anti-inflammatory drug that is used to treat acetaminophen poisoning
column12: mushroom poisoning and liver damage. Researchers
column13: such as Scofield
column14: have also studied its effects on the nervous system
column15: especially in the areas of addiction and pain perception. Wilson's clinical goals and Scofield's research on NAC made them ideal collaborators.\n\nThis project is really an elegant synthesis of basic science and clinical research
column16: using things we find have efficacy in the laboratory and taking them to the clinic
column17: said Scofield.\n\nWilson believes that partnerships between physicians and basic scientists can spur clinical advances. She credits the supportive environment within the department fostered by Chairman Scott Reeves
column18: M. D.

column20: M.D.
column21: for making such partnerships possible.\n\nThe research team chose spinal surgery patients for its pilot study because these patients often experience chronic pain before surgery and are more likely to be exposed to higher levels of opioids before
column22: during and after surgery. During surgery
column23: patients received a standard regimen of anesthesia in addition to a dose of NAC or a saline infusion. Information on patients' pain and opioid consumption was then collected.\n\nIn the 48 hours after surgery
column24: patients who were administered NAC via IV infusion (150 mg/kg) received 19% fewer opioid doses on average than patients who received saline. NAC patients also reported lower pain scores and took a longer time to request pain medication after their surgery than the saline patients. The researchers were especially encouraged to see that the beneficial effect seemed to last longer than the NAC was expected to remain in the body.\n\nWe've seen the impact of giving this medication persisting
column25: and I think that's significant
column26:
said Wilson. We're not seeing a rebound effect when that medication wears off.

This extended effect on pain perception mirrored previous findings from Scofield's laboratory research.

For heroin addiction
column27: we had seen in NAC preclinical studies that protection against relapse vulnerability is long lasting

column29: the hope is that it's something that has a long duration.\n\nNext
column30: the research team wants to investigate whether the findings can be translated to other procedures. They are currently enrolling patients undergoing minimally invasive hysterectomies in a larger trial. As more patients are enrolled
column31: the researchers will be able to conduct more in-depth statistical tests to improve their understanding of the effects of NAC on surgery-associated pain. This will help them to set the stage for future clinical trials of NAC during surgery.\n\nTo change practice

column6: LOS ANGELES—Imagine transforming the voting process—something considered an almost sacred fundamental right—into something akin to buying a lottery ticket. That’s what the Los Angeles city Ethics Commission would like to do to get more people to come out and vote.\n\nVoter turnout is at record lows for Los Angeles city elections. Less than 20 percent of registered voters on average came to the polls in 2013
column10: 000 prizes or one hundred $1
column11: 000 prizes.\n\nBut there has been criticism of the idea
column12: too.\n\nThe LA Times Editorial Board called it “one of the worst ideas we’ve heard in a long time
column13: ” noting that it “fails to address the deeper reasons why people don’t vote
column14: ” including apathy
column15: ignorance
column16:
or critical personal issues.

Others are concerned that monetary incentives could skew the outcome of an election by bringing uninformed voters to the polls. But the Ethics Commission says studies show that people who know they are going to vote are more likely to pay attention to the issues.

“If we weren’t dealing with a crisis
column17: we wouldn’t be considering any of this
column18: ” Hochman said. “For the people who don’t want voter drawings as an answer
column19:
we invite you to come up with some other solution that will drive significant more numbers to the polls.”

Groups such as the Municipal Elections Reform Commission have suggested that changing the dates of city elections from odd- to even-numbered years to coincide with larger elections would help. They also recommend holding fewer special elections to save time and money for the city and voters. Hochman says these changes could take years.

Federal law prohibits paying people to vote
column20: but the Ethics Commission says the federal law would not apply to a purely local election.\n\nCalifornia and Alaska are the only two states that allow incentives for voting
column21: although the money cannot be used to encourage people to vote for a specific candidate or measure.	P	2024-02-11 23:10:32	2024-02-11 23:37:19

column6: A consortium of federal agencies and nongovernmental organizations has published a report proposing a set of common measures and data-collection methods for use in asthma clinical research. Asthma Outcomes in Clinical Research: Report of the Asthma Outcomes Workshop
column10: asthma clinical research has lacked a common set of outcomes
column11: measures used by researchers to assess a disease during the course of a study. This lack of standardization has made it difficult to compare results between individual studies and to share data across studies
column12: thus hindering the progress of asthma research.\n\nThe report identifies standard definitions and methodologies for measuring seven groups of outcomes that are important in asthma clinical studies: symptoms
column13: exacerbations (asthma attacks)
column14: biomarkers (biological substances that indicate disease state)
column15: lung function
column16: quality of life
column17: asthma control questionnaire results
column18: and health care utilization and costs. By using the same set of outcome measures in asthma clinical studies
column19: researchers will be able compare their results more efficiently. This proposed standardization across asthma studies promises to enhance the development of prevention and treatment strategies and lead to improvements in the quality of asthma care.\n\nBased on the recommendations of the report
column20: NIH and other federal agencies will require the inclusion of the proposed outcomes in future government-funded asthma clinical research.	P	2024-02-11 23:10:32	2024-02-11 23:26:30

column6: (PhysOrg.com) -- Too much choice can be a bad thing—not just for the individual
column10: but did they really have a choice?” Americans tend to assume that what people do and what happens to them is under their control
column11: is a consequence of their choices
column12: and is their own personal responsibility.\n\nAlong with Nicole Stephens of Northwestern University and Hazel Rose Markus of Stanford University
column13: Savani looked at how thinking about choice affected people’s feelings on public policies. For example
column14: in some experiments
column15: participants watched a video of a person doing a set of routine daily activities in an apartment. Some people were told to push the space bar every time he made a choice; others were told to do so every time he touched an object for the first time. They were then asked their opinions on social issues.\n\nSimply thinking about ‘choice’ made people less likely to support policies promoting greater equality and benefits for society
column16: such as affirmative action
column17: a tax on fuel-inefficient cars
column18: or banning violent video games. Another experiment found that when people think about choice
column19: they are more likely to blame others for bringing bad events on themselves
column20: like having a heart attack or losing a job.\n\nSavani and his colleagues wondered if this was also true for people outside of the U. S.
column21: so they tried an experiment in India. After choosing among consumer objects like pens and chocolate bars
column22: both American students and Indian students were shown a photograph of a poor child and given a description of his life. Thinking about choice led Americans to be less empathetic
column23: but had no effect on Indians. “In America
column24: we make choices all the time—in the cafeteria
column25: in the supermarket
column26: in the shopping mall
column27: ” Savani says. He wonders if
column28: in the long run
column29: all those consumer choices might have a cumulative negative impact by making people less sympathetic towards others and less concerned about the collective good.	P	2024-02-11 23:10:32	2024-02-11 23:14:51

Mangosteen is a tropical fruit known for its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. It is native to the Southeast Asian regions. It is used to treat many health ailments. However
column10: and nausea. If left untreated
column11:
this condition can lead to an acid build-up in the body to dangerous levels – leading to shock and death (3).

Animal studies have shown the anticancer effects of mangosteen (4). But studies on humans are yet to be conducted. Mangosteen products are often marketed to cancer patients as dietary supplements.

Some research shows that these supplements may interfere with cancer treatment and adversely affect blood sugar levels (5). In another report
column12: certain antioxidant supplements were found to reduce the effectiveness of conventional radiation therapies (6).\n\nAs mangosteen supplements are often marketed for their antioxidant potential
column13: it is important to exercise caution.\n\nSome research has shown subjects experiencing gastrointestinal symptoms after consuming mangosteen for over 26 weeks. Some of these symptoms included bloating
column14: diarrhea
column15: gastric reflux
column16: and constipation (7).\n\nThe derivatives of mangosteen caused depression and sedation in rats. The effects had also resulted in decreased motor activity (8). However
column17: more studies in humans are required to establish these effects.\n\nThere is limited evidence if mangosteen can cause allergies. But anecdotal evidence suggests that it may cause reactions in people sensitive to the fruit. If you experience any reaction after consuming mangosteen
column18: stop intake and visit your doctor. Mild symptoms are a skin rash and stomach upset.\n\nThe safety of mangosteen during pregnancy or breastfeeding is not yet established. Hence
column19: stay safe and avoid use. You may consult your doctor regarding the same.\n\nMost of the adverse effects of mangosteen are yet to be established by concrete research. If you are usually susceptible to allergies or reactions
column20: you may want to talk to your doctor before taking the fruit.\n\nMangosteen was banned in the US by the FDA because it could be a host to import Asian fruit flies into the country. The ban was lifted owing to precautionary irradiation of the fruit
column21: which was a treatment done to disinfect it. The method of irradiation is still under controversy despite its claims that it does not compromise with the taste and nutrition of the fruit (9).\n\nHowever
column22: food supplements containing mangosteen continue to be banned by the US FDA. Such supplements are mostly unregistered
column23:
and not much is known if they may cause any adverse effects (10).

Can the adverse effects of mangosteen be prevented if the fruit is taken in the right dosage? We have explored it in the following section.

The dosage of mangosteen is dependent on several factors
column24: such as age
column25: health
column26: and medical conditions of the consumer. The composition of dietary supplements
column27: such as mangosteen-based proprietary health drinks
column28: is unavailable. There is no authentic literature available on the appropriate dosage of mangosteen that is to be consumed for preventing the adverse effects. More research is warranted in this regard. Hence
column29: please talk to your doctor regarding the dosage.\n\nThe term “mangosteen” is commonly used interchangeably with “kokum”. However
column30: the two are different. Learn more about the differences in the next section.\n\nMangosteen and kokum are often confused with each other due to their uncanny resemblance. This also is likely due to the fact that they belong to the Clusiaceae family. However
column31: they differ in taste and usage.\n\nMangosteen has a delicious sweet flavor with a hint of tanginess and is consumed fresh. On the other hand
column32: kokum has a sour and tangy taste and is used as a flavoring agent in Indian dishes to add a zesty touch. Plus
column33:
kokum is not consumed fresh.

When is mangosteen not healthy?

Mangosteen may not be healthy when taken in excess. In a few
column34: it may trigger allergies
column35: constipation
column36: bloating
column37: and acid reflux.\n\nNo
column38: mangosteen doesn’t raise blood pressure. In fact

which are substances that are broken down into uric acid.

Can the skin or rind of the mangosteen fruit cause any adverse reactions when consumed or applied topically?

Anecdotal evidence suggests that topical application of the skin or rind of mangosteen may cause allergic reactions in some people

A jump in the number of people with serious illness caused by group A Streptococcus—also referred to as Streptococcus pyogenes or Strep A—has made headlines recently. There has also been a higher than usual number of deaths from group A Streptococcus infections
column10: as well as superficial skin infections and skin infections known as pyoderma.\n\nHowever
column11: Group A Streptococcus can sometimes develop into invasive infections that put patients' lives at risk
column12: such as necrotizing fasciitis
column13: septicemia (blood poisoning) and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.\n\nTo generate this wide range of diseases in different parts of the body
column14: the organism has several factors that promote infection and allow the bacteria to invade
column15: colonize and survive in different tissues. These include molecules such as superantigens
column16: exotoxins and adhesins that help pathogens evade the host immune system.\n\nA new variant of group A Streptococcus called M1UK was first reported in the United Kingdom
column17: where it has been linked to an increase in scarlet fever cases as well as an increase in invasive infections.\n\nMembers of the M1UK sublineage exhibit an ability to enhance the expression of the superantigen SpeA due to a single genetic mutation. The over-production of SpeA may be responsible for increased transmission and survival
column18: as well as the aggressiveness of these infections
column19: although this is currently being studied.\n\nUp to approximately 10% of school-aged children will commonly carry these bacteria in their throats and upper respiratory tract without having any symptoms
column20: and over time will develop some level of immunity to it.\n\nIt is likely that during the COVID-19 pandemic
column21: children were at home and not being exposed to the bacteria as much as before and so their immune systems are probably not as good at fighting these infections. Without this exposure
column22: some children are likely to be more susceptible to infection.\n\nThe spread of the new M1UK strain is also probably why there's an increased number of cases
column23: although this is something that is currently being studied.\n\nGenerally
column24: Canadians should not be overly concerned because serious infections with group A Streptococcus are still quite rare.\n\nHowever
column25: people should also not ignore strep throat
column26: and should get treatment from a doctor and be wary of symptoms that might suggest an invasive infection.\n\nStrep throat requires treatment
column27: as untreated strep throat can lead to other problems including invasive infections.\n\nBecause group A Streptococcus are common and many carriers are asymptomatic
column28: it can be difficult to avoid exposure. Practicing good hand hygiene
column29: covering coughs and sneezes
column30: staying home when you're sick and not sending children to school if they have a very sore throat are all good measures.\n\nIf you believe you have a strep infection such as strep throat with painful swallowing
column31: fever
column32: swollen tonsils or a rash
column33: talk to a family physician to determine if the infection is caused by group A Streptococcus. A rapid strep test can be done with a throat swab. If the test is positive
column34: antibiotics can be prescribed.\n\nInvasive group A strep infections are very dangerous and are a medical emergency
column35: although initial symptoms may not be obvious. These could include fever
column36: chills
column37: flu-like symptoms and nausea or vomiting
column38:
but in particular red and warm skin infections that may be very painful and spread rapidly.

There is strong evidence that prior viral infections such as chickenpox can predispose people for developing invasive group A Streptococcus. Children with chickenpox should be watched carefully for symptoms of invasive group A Strep.

Currently
column39: there is no vaccine against group A Streptococcus
column40: although there is a vaccine for chickenpox. Multiple research teams around the world
column41: including our own lab
column42: are working towards developing an effective vaccine against this human pathogen.\n\nThis article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article.	P	2024-02-11 23:10:32	2024-02-11 23:13:49

column6: Many of the side effects of prunes may cause you to think twice before overconsuming this natural laxative. These cousins of the plum typically come in dried form. You can use these fruits in sweet and savory dishes like stews
column10: and medications also determine how intake of prunes can affect you. Here are a few side effects of eating prunes:\n\nPrunes contain a high concentration of acrylamide
column11: which is considered a carcinogen and a neurotoxin (1). Acrylamide is not naturally found in normal food
column12: except when it is cooked at temperatures above 100° C.\n\nAccording to Food and Agriculture Organization
column13: the amount of acrylamide required to cause neuropathic harm is about 500 times the daily dietary intake. So
column14: consuming prunes is relatively safe. However
column15: the carcinogenicity is a concern as prunes were found to be highly carcinogenic to the animals that were tested in labs.\n\nIf you have ever wondered ‘Do prunes make you poop?’ They do. If consumed in excess
column16: the insoluble fiber in prunes can cause or worsen diarrhea. This is why you need to avoid them when you have diarrhea (2). There have also been certain cases of people who had experienced diarrhea post the ingestion of prunes and prune juice (3). But why do prunes make you poop and worsen diarrhea? This can be attributed to the laxative property of prunes. They are natural laxatives as they contain a laxative compound called sorbitol. So
column17: an unregulated dose or having too many of these fruits can easily lead to diarrhea
column18: electrolyte imbalance or even an allergic reaction.\n\nSome sources also talk about the dietary fructose intolerance found in many individuals
column19: which can also lead to abdominal pain and diarrhea. Prunes contain high amounts of sugar
column20: which might trigger such a problem.\n\nOne serving of 6 uncooked prunes contains 137 calories and 22 grams of sugar. That sure is a little on the higher end. And a one-cup serving of prune juice contains about 185 calories. Some believe that the fiber in prunes can promote satiety and possibly help with weight loss. However
column21:
taking them in excess can have the opposite effect.

Prunes also have a high glycemic load (how much any particular food will raise a person’s glucose levels post consumption) (4). This means overconsuming prunes can elevate your blood sugar levels more than most other fruits.

Prunes are nutritious and can be beneficial for digestion and weight loss. However
column22: excess consumption of prunes may result in gastrointestinal issues. They contain complex carbohydrates and sugars that do not completely break down in the digestive tract (5). So
column23: when the sugars reach the colon
column24:
the bacteria start feeding on these undigested carbohydrates.

These bacteria are responsible for intestinal gas and bloating. This can also lead to farting. You can take alpha-D-galactosidase before eating prunes as it reduces intestinal gas by breaking down the complex carbohydrates before they reach your gut.

Prunes are mostly used as irritant laxatives. However
column25: those who suffer from frequent constipation should not rely on prunes completely to clear their digestive system. This can lead to laxative dependency after a certain period of usage
column26: which can aggravate the condition and cause nutrient deficiency among other complications (6).\n\n@Sectioned
column27: a mental health blogger
column28: explained how she found out about the laxative effect of prunes. She says
column29: “Don’t take too many. Once
column30: before I knew the laxative effect of prune juice
column31: I drank a whole liter in one go. That’s how I know it works. Now
column32: I just drink a glass (i).”\n\nPrunes are rich in iron and
column33: like most iron-rich foods
column34: can cause dark stools if taken in excess.\n\nPrunes are high in sugar and calories (7). While they can be a healthy snack option
column35: their excessive consumption may lead to weight gain in pregnant women. However
column36: limited data is available in this regard. They are also rich in dietary fiber and consuming them in excess may lead to several digestive issues. While pregnant women are sensitive to changes in their digestive system
column37: it is important to eat prunes in moderation to prevent these issues.\n\nIn addition
column38: prunes have a moderate glycemic index that may cause a gradual increase in blood sugar levels (8). Hence
column39: it is essential to monitor the intake of prunes
column40: especially if you are a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes or are at high risk of developing it.\n\nPrunes have their own set of side effects
column41: but you can still consume them in moderation. Also
column42: consult your doctor if you experience any side effects from eating prunes.\n\n“Yes. Since prunes are rich in soluble fiber content
column43: this slows down the absorption of the natural sugar they contain. They are low-glycemic fruits
column44: perfect for people with diabetes. But it’s essential to note that quantity is important. If someone with diabetes eats too many prunes
column45: their sugar intake may be too high. So
column46: two to three prunes per day is a good serving size for people with diabetes
column47: ” says Eva De Angelis
column48: Dietitian Nutritionist.\n\nEva De Angelis says
column49: “It depends. While some foods have been linked to acid reflux
column50: the effects can be different for different people. And this also applies to prunes. For some
column51: this dried fruit can be a healthy choice and even make them feel better. Yet
column52: for others
column53: prunes can lead to acid reflux.”\n\n“No. Prunes made just from plums
column54: with no added sugar
column55: are nourishing and rich in fiber
column56: calcium
column57: boron
column58: and potassium
column59: all essential minerals for bone health. A serving size of 5 to 6 prunes per day is a good amount. Yet
column60: like any dried fruit
column61: they are high in natural sugars
column62:
so eating too much can be detrimental.” says Eva.

What happens if you eat prunes every day?

Prunes are loaded with many beneficial nutrients. However
column63: eating them in excess may cause diarrhea.\n\nPrunes contain sorbitol
column64: which is hard to digest for some people. This may trigger stomach aches
column65: bloating
column66: and mild nausea.\n\nEva De Angelis says
column67: “This greatly depends on each individual and on the type of IBS they have. For example
column68: if you have IBS with mostly constipation
column69: prunes can act as a natural laxative due to their high fiber content. But if you experience IBS with mostly diarrhea
column70: they are not the best choice.”\n\nDiscover the potential side effects of eating too many prunes. Watch the video below to know how this delicious fruit can affect your health and well-being.	P	2024-02-11 23:10:32	2024-02-12 00:02:55

MEXICO CITY—Mexico began the process of extraditing drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman to the United States
column10:
mostly to the U. S. He is wanted in various U.S. states and his July escape deeply embarrassed the government of President Enrique Pena Nieto and strained ties between the countries.

Guzman’s attorney Juan Pablo Badillo has said the defense has already filed six motions to challenge extradition requests.

Badillo said that his client shouldn’t be extradited to the U. S. because “our country must respect national sovereignty
column11: the sovereignty of its institutions to impart justice.”\n\nOn Saturday
column12: a Mexican federal law enforcement official said the quickest Guzman could be extradited would be six months
column13: but even that is not likely because of the many appeals filed by his lawyers. He said that the appeals are usually turned down
column14: but each one means a judge has to schedule a hearing.\n\n“That can take weeks or months
column15: and that delays the extradition
column16: ” he said on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to comment. “We’ve had cases that take six years.”\n\nMexico’s willingness to extradite Guzman is a sharp turnaround from the last time he was captured in 2014
column17: when then-Attorney General Jesus Murillo Karam said the extradition would happen only after he finished his sentence in Mexico in “300 or 400 years.”\n\nGuzman was re-apprehended on Friday after a shootout between gunmen and Mexican marines at the home in Los Mochis
column18:
a seaside city in Guzman’s home state of Sinaloa. Five suspects were killed and six others arrested. One marine was injured.

Mexican authorities say actor Sean Penn’s contacts with Guzman helped them track the fugitive down — even if he slipped away from an initial raid on the hideout where the Hollywood actor apparently met him.

Penn’s article on Guzman was published late Saturday by Rolling Stone magazine
column19: a day after the drug lord’s recapture. In it
column20: Penn wrote of elaborate security precautions
column21: but also said that as he flew to Mexico on Oct 2 for the meeting
column22: “I see no spying eyes
column23:
but I assume they are there.”

He was apparently right.

A Mexican federal law enforcement official
column24: speaking on condition of anonymity because he was not permitted to comment on the issue
column25: told the Associated Press the Penn interview led authorities to Guzman in the area of Tamazula
column26: a rural part of Durango state.	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-11 23:51:47

Few Armed Forces personnel seek help for mental health disorders and novel approaches will be needed to encourage personnel at risk of PTSD
column10: depression or alcohol abuse to seek help will be needed.\n\nBetween 2001 and 2014
column11: the UK deployed more than 220550 Armed Forces personnel to the Afghanistan and Iraq conflicts. Among personnel who were deployed
column12: an estimated 4% developed PTSD
column13: 20% developed psychological distress and 16% developed alcohol misuse—similar rates to personnel who were not deployed. Personnel who were deployed in combat roles have higher rates of probable PTSD and alcohol misuse.\n\nIn the UK
column14: mental health support and treatment for Armed Forces personnel consists of psychoeducational briefings
column15: peer support programmes to assist with traumatic stress
column16: decompression before returning home from deployment and clinical services comprising a mixture of uniformed and civilian healthcare professionals. However
column17: approximately half of military personnel with a probable mental health disorder do not seek help. Additionally many delay seeking help or do not finish treatment.\n\nScreening has therefore been proposed as a way to identify those at risk of mental health problems on return from deployment and prompt them to seek help. Various forms of post-deployment screening exist and are used in the US
column18: Canada
column19: Australia and the Netherlands.\n\nIn the study
column20: led by King's Centre for Military Health Research at King's College London (UK)
column21: researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a particular type of screening. On return from deployment
column22: all 10190 personnel involved in the trial were asked to complete a computerised mental health assessment.\n\nPersonnel in the screening group were then offered the opportunity to view tailored mental health advice based on their likelihood of having a mental health disorder. If they agreed
column23: they were told what mental health issue they probably had
column24: and were urged to seek help by speaking either to a unit welfare officer (for moderate symptoms)
column25: a medical officer (more severe symptoms)
column26: or told that no professional support was needed if no risk was identified. Personnel in the control group were offered the general mental health advice offered in the UK military—as they would have been if they had not undergone screening. They were told that there were many ways to seek help and were given examples of support provided. All participants were then followed up between 10 and 24 months later.\n\nTwo-thirds (65%; 3619/5577) of personnel who were offered tailored advice agreed to see it
column27: while the remaining 35% declined. Higher ranks and older personnel were more likely to see the tailored advice
column28: and personnel with probable PTSD
column29: anxiety or depression were more likely to view it compared to people who did not have any mental health symptoms.\n\nAt follow-up
column30: there were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of the prevalence of PTSD (11%)
column31: depression or anxiety (6%) and alcohol abuse (12%) (table 4). There was also no difference in the rate of health seeking or pharmaceutical use between the two groups
column32: with 12% (496/3996) of personnel in the screening group using a mental health service in the follow-up period
column33: compared to 13% (318/2369) in the control group (table 5).\n\nAt follow-up
column34: about a third of personnel who had probable PTSD
column35: depression or anxiety (excluding alcohol misuse) at the start of the study had sought mental health care over the past 12 months
column36: with no difference between the control and screening groups (35.8% (53/148) in the control group vs. 32.9% (82/249) in the screening group) (appx p.5). Help-seeking behaviour among personnel with probable PTSD
column37: depression or anxiety was similar irrespective of whether personnel chose to view the tailored advice or not.\n\nDifferent countries use different approaches to post-deployment screening and our study looked at one particular type of screening
column38: as it was the form that was most likely to be introduced in the UK military. We found no evidence to support the idea that post deployment screening via a computerised assessment followed by tailored mental health advice helped improve the mental health of personnel over and above general mental health advice. Countries that have already introduced post-deployment screening are not able to assess effectiveness via a randomised controlled trial as they cannot generate a no-screening group
column39: but they should consider monitoring the outcomes of their programmes
column40: says lead author Professor Roberto Rona
column41: King's College London.\n\nThe authors note that the findings from the trial may not be entirely generalizable to other screening programmes
column42: because other programmes use approaches such as repeated assessments over time
column43: or face-to-face interviews (as is the case in the US screening programme).\n\nUnderstandably
column44: military forces are keen to protect the mental health of their personnel who carry out highly challenging duties on behalf of their countries. The question is what can be done to make a positive difference by protecting the mental health of personnel and decreasing the burden of mental illness on individuals
column45: their families and UK society as a whole. More research is needed to improve the mental health of UK Armed Forces personnel and other approaches could include good leadership training
column46: peer and family support programmes and further improving the quality and accessibility of military mental health services
column47: says co-author Professor Neil Greenberg
column48: King's College London.\n\nWriting in a linked Comment
column49: Dr Alexander C McFarlane
column50: University of Adelaide
column51: Australia
column52: notes that a potential confounding issue with this study design is the fact that by filling in the self-report measures
column53: both groups had the opportunity to reflect on their obvious levels of symptomatic distress... which might have minimised the ability to find differences between groups. He also highlights the importance of ensuring adequate care is available when personnel do seek help: Even if an individual did present to mental health services in the UK military as part of (this) study
column54: this did not guarantee that an evidence-based intervention was offered
column55: even when a general practitioner was consulted.	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-11 22:38:40

column6: BANGKOK—The European Union expanded its sanctions against Burma’s military leaders and army-controlled companies ahead of a regional meeting to discuss the worsening crisis after army leaders deposed the elected government.\n\nThe Council of the European Union’s latest sanctions target 10 individuals and two military-controlled companies already subject to sanctions by the United States
column10: and other measures. EU citizens and businesses are banned from doing business or providing funds to them without special permission.\n\n“Today’s decision is a sign of the EU’s unity and determination in condemning the brutal actions of the military junta
column11: and aims at effecting change in the junta’s leadership
column12: ” the EU said in a statement.\n\n“Today’s decision also sends a clear message to the military leadership: continuing on the current path will only bring further suffering and will never grant any legitimacy
column13: ” it said.\n\nSince the coup
column14: security forces have killed at least 738 protesters and bystanders
column15: according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners
column16: which monitors casualties and arrests. It says more than 3
column17: 200 people are still detained
column18:
among the nation’s deposed civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi and President Win Myint.

The EU already had an embargo on sales to Burma of arms and equipment that can be used for internal repression; an export ban on dual-use goods for use by the military and border guard police; export restrictions on equipment for monitoring communications that could be used for internal repression; and a prohibition on military training for and military cooperation with the army.

Last week
column19: the U. S. S&P 500 said it was removing India’s Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. from its sustainability index due to its alleged dealings with Burma authorities. Adani did not respond to a request for comment on that move.\n\nFormer U. N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon on Monday exhorted the U.N. Security Council to act immediately to halt the violence and protect civilians. So far
column20: the council has not taken such action
column21:
which would likely be blocked by China and Russia.

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations—which is holding a summit on Burma this month—maintains a policy of “non-interference” in each others’ political matters and has rejected the idea of imposing sanctions against the junta.

Ban urged ASEAN to send a high-level delegation to Burma. He said he had tried unsuccessfully to make a diplomatic visit himself.	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-11 23:36:32

Mariani said that because the region is growing at an unprecedented rate
column17: everything
column18: including subways
column19: are now routing northerly. As the need for density grows
column20: high-rises won’t be isolated to Toronto’s core.\n\n“We know the way this city is building and expanding. Townhouses may not be the affordable entry-level option in the GTA anymore; it could be the condo option
column21: ” he said. “No builder out there looks at what they’re going to sell for just the next year—they’re looking at the next five years
column22: 10 years
column23: down the road. We’re always trying to forecast what’s coming down the pipe.”\n\nCountryWide had 18 active sites in 2015

Parents need to take the first step and show support to rebuild the relationship. Don’t expect your child to make the first move; you do it. This will make your child realize that you are serious about them and go a long way in developing a strong and secured bond.

What is the most psychologically damaging thing you can say to a child?

There are several psychologically damaging things that parents can say to a child. But most importantly
column130:
“I don’t love you” or saying nothing at all seriously hurts your child.

How do you deal with a disrespectful grown daughter?

Engage with your daughter
column131: acknowledge the mistake or hurt you may have caused

and also learn to set boundaries; these may help deal with a disrespectful grown daughter.

How do you let go of a child who hates you?

Try to listen to your child
column133: letting them know how much love you have
column134: and also try to change yourself to avoid the same mistake (if you begin communicating again).\n\nDiscover insights and unveil the compelling reasons your grown kids might harbor deep resentment towards you. (AP) -- The first study of U. S. health care workers with swine flu found that many didn't do enough to protect themselves against the virus.\n\nResearchers focused on 13 nurses and other health care workers who were likely infected at work in the early days of the U. S. outbreak. They found that only half always wore gloves
column10: especially if - as some fear - the virus mutates into a deadlier form.\n\nThe study is being published this week in a CDC publication
column11: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.\n\nThe 80 cases of health care workers is out of the nearly 18
column12: 000 confirmed and probable U. S. cases reported as of last Friday. Those numbers suggest health care workers are underrepresented in the case counts
column13: CDC officials said.\n\nAbout 1
column14: 600 people have been hospitalized and at least 44 died
column15: according to CDC numbers. Many of the victims were younger adults
column16: children and people with other illnesses. About 40 percent of those hospitalized have been people with asthma
column17: diabetes
column18: heart disease and other medical conditions
column19: said Dr. Daniel Jernigan
column20: a CDC flu expert.\n\nWidespread cases in 17 states - particularly in the Northeast - suggest swine flu will continue through July and August and into the fall and winter
column21: he said.\n\nIn some earlier flu pandemics
column22: the new virus essentially elbowed out other flu strains. It's likely that swine flu will circulate along with seasonal flu bugs in the fall
column23: Jernigan said.\n\n©2009 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published

Aguero: Brazil Collapse Can Happen to Anyone

BELO HORIZONTE
column11: Brazil (AP) — Germany’s 7-1 thrashing of five-time champion Brazil has left no doubt among Argentina’s players about the challenge they face in the World Cup final on Sunday. Striker Sergio Aguero says he and his Argentine teammates obviously took notice of the rout.“Germany is a great team. What happened to Brazil could happen to any team
column12: ” he said.But
column13: Aguero added
column14: the Germans also have reason to be concerned
column15: “knowing that we have players who can create danger up front — We’re in the final for a reason.”After injuring his left thigh in Argentina’s last group-stage match against Nigeria
column16: the Manchester City striker was sidelined for two knockout games before going on as a substitute in the semifinal Wednesday against the Netherlands. He failed to have an impact in the attack but scored the third penalty in Argentina’s 4-2 shootout win.“When you come back from injury
column17: in the back of your mind you are worried about it happening again
column18: ” Aguero said. “When you miss three matches in a World Cup with the rhythm the guys have you realize you are lacking something.“But if I get called up to play in the final I will try to find the energy from wherever to do it as well as possible.”Argentina hadn’t advanced beyond the quarterfinals since the 1990 World Cup
column19: so the country is euphoric about the team’s success in Brazil.Unlike Germany
column20: Argentina has advanced with single-goal margins against its opponents and couldn’t score before the shootout against the Netherlands. Four years ago in South Africa
column21: Argentina lost 4-0 to Germany in the quarterfinals.“At this point who is favorite
column22: who is not
column23: it doesn’t make a difference
column24: ” midfielder Maxi Rodriguez said. “Both teams feel a responsibility to go all the way. We’re going to do our part to make it.”	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-11 22:18:42

but they may also feel stuck due to their depressive symptoms
column11: ” says Ernesto Lira de la Rosa
column12: PhD
column13: a New York City–based clinical psychologist and an adviser for the Hope for Depression Research Foundation. “Although they know that doing things with their partner will be good for them
column14: they sometimes do not have the mental and physical energy.”\n\nIf depression is negatively affecting your relationship
column15: it’s important to work together with your partner to address it. In fact
column16: not doing so can have serious consequences. One study of more than 20
column17: 200 Norwegian married couples
column18: published in 2015 in BMC Public Health
column19: showed that rates of divorce are significantly higher among couples in which one partner experiences some form of mental distress
column20: such as depression
column21: than in couples in which neither partner experiences mental distress.\n\nHere are five signs that depression is taking a toll on your relationship (plus
column22: five tips for lessening its impact).\n\nAnhedonia — loss of interest
column23: enjoyment
column24: or pleasure in things once enjoyed — is a hallmark symptom of depression
column25: according to Cleveland Clinic.\n\nIf you have depression
column26: the condition can affect all parts of your life
column27: including activities you used to find fun and that once made you happy
column28: per Cleveland Clinic. This can be difficult for some partners without depression to understand.\n\n“If the couple usually enjoys going out together for movies
column29: dinner
column30: time with mutual friends
column31: and one partner withdraws from these activities because of depression
column32: it may become a point of contention for the other partner
column33: ” says Stacey Neal
column34: MD
column35: a psychiatrist at Kaiser Permanente in Baltimore.\n\nDepression is linked to low self-esteem and self-criticism
column36: according to Mayo Clinic. It can make some people with the condition feel like there’s something wrong with them
column37: and that other people around them — including their partner — are judging them
column38: explains Dr. Lira de la Rosa. As a result
column39: some people with depression may also question whether their partner truly wants to be in a relationship with them
column40: he adds.\n\n“Some partners may internalize that something is wrong with them and may feel that their partner does not find them desirable
column41: ” says Lira de la Rosa. “This can translate to them spending a lot of time alone and perhaps saying no to their partner when they would like to do some activities together.”\n\nSome people with depression may become withdrawn
column42: even from family and loved ones
column43: according to Mayo Clinic.\n\n“For instance
column44: this can lead to someone with depression not sharing with their partner that they are going through a tough time or asking for support from their partner
column45: ” says Lira de la Rosa. “As a result
column46: the other person in the relationship may not be aware of what is happening or know how to best support their partner.”\n\nHaving support from loved ones can be a key part of managing depression
column47: and becoming isolated from others can worsen your symptoms
column48: according to Mayo Clinic.\n\nWhile all couples have conflict — and some conflict can be healthy
column49: experts say — conflicts tend to happen more frequently among couples in which one partner has depression. Research shows that many people with depression have more negative interactions than positive interactions with their spouse or partner
column50: compared with people without depression.\n\nOne potential reason: Heightened irritability and sensitivity are common symptoms of depression. Sometimes in relationships
column51: these symptoms can cause issues that may seem small or innocuous to one partner — like playful teasing
column52: for example — to be misconstrued by the partner with depression
column53: says Dr. Neal.\n\nAnother common type of misunderstanding
column54: which Lira de la Rosa often sees among his patients
column55: has to do with not knowing the best ways to support each other. For instance
column56: the partner with depression might feel that their partner doesn’t check in on them in ways that they find helpful
column57: or that their partner doesn’t care. “When in reality
column58: the other partner may have tried to check in and offer support and it was rejected
column59: ” says Lira de la Rosa.\n\n“This then creates a cycle of someone feeling that they are not getting the support they need
column60: but they may not see that their behavior and emotions may push supportive people away
column61: ” he adds.\n\nIf you find that depression is hindering your sex life
column62: you’re not alone. Depression leads to sexual dysfunction in almost 83 percent of women and 63 percent of men with the condition
column63: research shows.\n\nThis can happen for several reasons
column64: including symptoms such as fatigue and lack of energy. What’s more
column65: certain antidepressants can weaken sex drive
column66: cause erectile dysfunction
column67: or make it difficult to reach orgasm
column68: per Mayo Clinic.\n\nIf depression is negatively affecting your sex life
column69: it can pose several challenges for a relationship. Sexual problems may be something you find distressing
column70: which in turn may exacerbate your depressive symptoms. Or
column71: for instance
column72:
some partners may not understand why sex has dwindled and could feel confused or even hurt as a result.

RELATED: How to Have a Healthy Sex Life if Depression Is Getting in the Way

While living with depression can feel overwhelming
column73: the good news is that there are steps people can take to feel better
column74: which can in turn help improve romantic relationships too. These five tips can help.\n\nOne of the best ways to lessen the effects of depression on your relationship is to make sure your symptoms are treated. For your best chance at symptom relief
column75: it’s important to be consistent with your treatment (or seek treatment from a mental health professional
column76: if you haven’t already). Psychotherapy and medication are the most common and effective treatments for depression
column77: according to Mayo Clinic.\n\nLearning and practicing healthy communication skills
column78: such as being honest with each other in respectful ways
column79: validating each other’s feelings
column80: and finding compromise
column81: can help couples address their challenges together
column82: according to The JED Foundation
column83: a nonprofit geared toward improving emotional health and preventing suicide among teens and young adults.\n\nBy going to therapy or counseling together
column84: couples can learn how to address depressive symptoms and any other issues together as a team
column85: per The Family Institute at Northwestern University. It’s also a great way to learn and practice healthy communication skills.\n\nAs the saying goes
column86: you can’t pour from an empty cup. Self-care (any activity you do to take care of yourself so that you can be healthy
column87: well
column88: and productive) is a key part of a healthy relationship
column90: an intimate partner violence prevention organization. Regularly practicing self-care can help you feel better and allow you to be a more present partner
column91: per McNulty Counseling and Wellness.\n\nAs noted earlier
column92: there are several reasons that depression can put a strain on your sex life
column94: sexual dysfunction
column95: and the side effects of antidepressants.\n\nIf you feel your depression is negatively affecting your sex life (and your relationship as a result)
column96: there are steps you can take to lessen its impact. For starters
column97: it can help to tell your partner about what you’re going through and why your depression is impacting your sex drive
column98: according to Mayo Clinic. And if both partners feel ready to be intimate again
column99: it can help to start small and slow and gradually ease into it.\n\nIt can also help to talk to your doctor about what you’re experiencing
column100: because they can help you narrow down the cause. For instance
column101: if you take antidepressants and they’re causing sexual side effects that don’t go away
column102: your doctor may opt to adjust your medication dose or switch you to a different antidepressant

A new study by Illinois State University's Andrés Vidal-Gadea is breaking ground in the field of muscular dystrophy research.\n\nPublished Tuesday in Proceedings of The National Academy of Science of the United States of America
column10: also pioneered new methods of studying C. elegans in more natural environments
column11: all with the aim of seeing if exercise produces long-term beneficial effects for muscular dystrophy patients.\n\nRather than just grown on top of a petri plate
column12: as is tradition
column13: we could watch them burrow
column14: said Vidal-Gadea
column15: an assistant professor of molecular neuroethology
column16: who employs the worms in a variety of neurological studies. The new method brought out the phenotype of the disease—or led to the worms displaying the illness.\n\nStudents in the lab altered the exercise regime for worms to mimic different activities. Some C. elegans simply sat near food. Others swam to mirror high-frequency/low impact exercise such as jogging. Still others burrowed through gelatin to give the same effect as weight-lifting. Over time
column17: worms that exercised built up muscles at different levels
column18: but saw no change in the length of life or in the course of disease.\n\nIt's unfortunate
column19: but our interpretation is that the exercise tested does not impact the course of the disease
column20: said Vidal-Gadea.\n\nThe work touches close to home for Vidal-Gadea
column21: who worked with patients with muscular dystrophy when he was an undergraduate student studying at the University of Victoria in British Columbia
column22: Canada. At times
column23: clients who would try different methods of exercise could end up worse off than when they started. That was brutal to see. They were trading their health for a chance to get better
column24: but there is nothing in the literature that is conclusive about what helps
column25: he said.\n\nThe failure is not in the exercise itself
column26: but how the disease operates
column27: noted Vidal-Gadea. He compared muscles to the engine of a car that provide force. You can build up the engine and gather more force
column28: he said. But the problem isn't the engine
column29: it's in how the force is transmitted. So just building muscles alone is like trying to put a Formula 1 engine into a little Volkswagen bug when the transmission is broken. You might just tear your car apart. Now
column30: if you only look at some of the parameters like maximal RPMs of the engine
column31: you may be led to believe that the treatment helped.\n\nThe three-year study will also help scientists better understand the chain of events when humans develop muscular dystrophy
column32: and the symptoms that arise. We know that when people get muscular dystrophy
column33: the gene is broken and muscles die
column34: said Vidal-Gadea
column35: but there are a lot of things that happen in between that we don't know. He added that piecing together the chain will give scientists a view into what damage is caused by the disease and what is sparked by the muscles trying to fight back.\n\nOne step along the chain Vidal-Gadea's team examined was the amount of calcium released in the muscles of those battling Duchenne muscular dystrophy. There is a build-up of calcium that is released when the muscles contract
column36: said Vidal-Gadea. For those who have muscular dystrophy
column37: the amount of calcium released can be notably higher. The study examined the changes in calcium as the worms moved. We can begin to see where and when the calcium in the muscles becomes dysregulated. This gives us potential targets to go after to make improvements for those with muscular dystrophy.\n\nEven more striking
column38: in several cases
column39: the students were able to prevent dystrophic animals from developing signs of sickness. It was very few cases
column40: and the illness did not go away
column41: but the C. elegans did not show any symptoms of it in their actions
column42: said Vidal-Gadea. Our next steps will be to explore what chain of events might have led to the reversal.\n\nThe lab will continue to work with the help of NIH funding. Students involved include graduate
column43: undergraduate
column44: and high school students
column45: along with collaboration with individuals at the University of Illinois and the Fred Hutch Center in Seattle
column46: Washington. We use a wide array of techniques that can be complicated
column47: said Vidal-Gadea. The work these students are doing is propelling them in terms of research and moving toward their goals of medical school or lab experience.	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-11 22:14:14

column6: TUESDAY
column10: your sleep may be more restless
column11: and the big one is that you're going to feel some daytime impairment
column12: usually in terms of being tired or sleepy
column13:
he says.

And he says patients are likely to be preoccupied with images from their nightmares while awake.

Krakow says  while the nightmares may have been caused by the same trauma that caused PTSD
column14: the disorder alone isn't likely to fuel  nightmares over a long  time. Instead
column15: he says
column16: chronic nightmares are both trauma-induced and a learned behavior.\n\n[The new therapy] permits us and the patient to explore treating the nightmare directly
column17: says Krakow.\n\nKrakow and his colleagues worked with 168 women
column18: 95 percent of whom had moderate to severe PTSD. Ninety-seven percent had experienced rape or sexual assault; 77 percent also reported a life-threatening sexual assault
column19: and 58 percent also had experienced repeated sexual abuse in childhood or adolescence.\n\nKrakow's team randomly divided the women into two groups of 80 and 88. The first group continued to receive whatever treatment they already were  getting
column20: while the second group received three sessions of so-called imagery rehearsal therapy.\n\nDuring those sessions
column21: which involved four to eight women at a time
column22: therapists encouraged the women to recognize that their nightmares were trauma-induced and a learned behavior. In the first session
column23: they were also coached in pleasant imagery exercises.\n\nOne week later
column24: the women wrote about a single nightmare. The therapist told them to change anything they wanted about the nightmare
column25: then to rehearse the new dream for 10 to 15 minutes. Once they left the session
column26: the women had to rehearse the new dream for five to 20 minutes per day.\n\nIn the third session
column27: the women discussed their progress with the group and asked questions about PTSD
column28: nightmares and sleep.\n\nThree months after they started the program
column29: the women were asked about the quality of  their sleep
column30: frequency of nightmares and severity of PTSD symptoms. At the six-month mark
column31: the women returned for a personal interview
column32: where the researchers asked similar questions.\n\nGenerally speaking
column33: people [were] able to reduce their nightmares anywhere from 50 to 80 percent
column34: says Krakow. In some cases
column35: the nightmares disappeared entirely
column36: although the technique didn't work at all for some survivors.\n\nKrakow says most people who use the technique  usually will report fewer nightmares
column37: less intense nightmares or a different attitude towards their dreams. Eventually
column38: he says they may experience all three.\n\nRosalind Cartwright
column39: who heads the psychology department at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago
column40: says similar patterns of chronic nightmares also are  found in Holocaust survivors and Vietnam veterans.\n\nDreams of this kind tend to be repetitive and not self-resolving
column41: says Cartwright. They don't just fade the way bad experiences usually do. You have no way of coping with it unless you have some focused program during the day.\n\nShe says image rehearsal therapy lets patients guide their nightmares to a better end
column42: one without trauma.\n\nIn waking
column43: he has them get a sense of control over that imagery.  It is a very focused kind of treatment
column44: and very quick
column45:
says Cartwright.

What To Do

You can visit Krakow's Center for Sleep Medicine and Nightmare Treatment or find out about nightmares from the Association for the Study of Dreams.

ABCNews.com also has this story on nightmare therapy.	P	2024-02-11 22:10:33	2024-02-12 01:13:00

column6: WASHINGTON—U. S. President Joe Biden and German Chancellor Angela Merkel agreed to disagree on Thursday about a Russian pipeline project that Washington opposes
column10: a decision that drew criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike. But Biden said he and Merkel were united in their belief that Russia should not use energy as a geopolitical weapon.\n\n“Good friends can disagree
column11:

The first complete update in five years of the U. S. guidelines for preventing and treating HIV-associated opportunistic infections has been released by the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in cooperation with the HIV Medicine Association of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA).\n\nThe new Guidelines for Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in HIV-Infected Adults and Adolescents apply state-of-the-art science and medicine to 29 infectious diseases of concern. More than 140 medical experts contributed their knowledge to this edition of the guidelines
column10: these infections continue to threaten the health of many people infected with HIV
column11: says John T. Brooks
column12: M. D.
column13: co-author of the guidelines and leader of the HIV Clinical Epidemiology Team in CDC's Division of HIV/AIDS Prevention. It is critical that health care providers
column14: especially newer clinicians who may have less experience with opportunistic infections
column15: remain able to recognize the signs and symptoms of these infections and know how to provide the most effective preventive care and treatment.\n\nThe new guidelines combine what were previously two separate publications
column16:
one for the prevention of opportunistic infections (last published in 2002) and one for their treatment (first published in 2004).

Major changes to the guidelines include

* Emphasis on the important role of effective antiretroviral therapy in augmenting immune function
column17: which is pivotal to preventing and managing opportunistic infections\n\n* Information on the diagnosis and management of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome
column18: a condition in which the immune system begins to recover
column19:
but then responds to a previously acquired opportunistic infection with an overwhelming inflammatory response that worsens the symptoms of infection

* Information on the prevention and treatment of hepatitis B and C infections

* Information on interferon-gamma release assays for the detection of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

* Updated information on interactions between antiretroviral drugs and drugs used to treat opportunistic infections

* A new section on malaria and other tropical diseases that may become opportunistic infections in HIV-infected immigrants to the United States and in HIV-infected American travelers

HIV-associated opportunistic infections in the United States often occur in people who are unaware that they have HIV; in such cases
column20: the opportunistic infection may be the first sign of late-stage HIV disease. HIV-associated opportunistic infections also tend to occur among Americans who are aware of their HIV infection but are not receiving treatment for it
column21: who do not or cannot take antiretroviral therapy
column22: who take antiretroviral therapy but fail to benefit from it
column23: or who do not receive needed preventive care for an opportunistic infection.\n\nA draft of the new guidelines was released in June 2008 for public comment
column24: and an early edition of the new guidelines was published online on March 24. The finalized new Guidelines for Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in HIV-Infected Adults and Adolescents are accessible at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr5804.pdf and http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5804a1.htm. These guidelines
column25: as well as all federal HIV prevention and treatment guidelines
column26: can be found on the AIDSInfo Web site at http://www.aidsinfo.nih.gov/Guidelines/Default.aspx?MenuItem=Guidelines.\n\nA final draft of the corresponding pediatric version of these guidelines
column27: Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections among HIV-Exposed and HIV-Infected Children
column28: is under review and will be published later this year.	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-11 23:46:26

column15: which is defined as was defined as systolic blood pressure of 140 to 159 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure — the “bottom” number that shows how much pressure blood exerts on artery walls when the heart rests between beats — of 90 to 100 mmHg.\n\nNone of the participants had ever taken blood pressure medication

column20: according to the study

they tended to have lower total cholesterol levels as well as lower levels of “bad” LDL cholesterol.

One limitation of the study is that it included only white people and most of the participants were male. Results might be different for women or for people from other racial or ethnic groups.

Even so
column30: the findings suggest that patients may need multiple blood pressure measurements seated and standing to better identify individuals who have an increased risk for heart attacks and strokes
column31: particularly among younger adults.\n\nAfter adjusting for average blood pressure taken over 24 hours
column32: an exaggerated blood pressure response to standing remained an independent predictor of adverse heart events or stroke.\n\n“The results of the study confirmed our initial hypothesis — a pronounced increase in blood pressure from lying to standing could be prognostically important in young people with high blood pressure

column6: HONOLULU—U. S. scientists declared Tuesday that two active Hawaii volcanoes—one where lava destroyed hundreds of homes in 2018 and another where lava recently stalled before reaching a crucial Big Island highway—have stopped erupting.\n\n“Kilauea is no longer erupting
column10: the observatory’s scientist in charge.\n\nLava-viewers in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park enjoyed the added rare marvel of being able to see Mauna Loa’s smaller neighbor
column11: Kilauea
column12:
erupting at the same time.

Kilauea had been erupting since September 2021. A 2018 Kilauea eruption destroyed more than 700 residences.

Mauna Loa lava didn’t pose a threat to any communities
column13: but got within 1.7 miles (2.7 kilometers) of a major highway that connects the east and west sides of the island.\n\nHon called the two-week spectacle
column14: which is a typical timespan for Mauna Loa
column15: “my favorite eruption.”\n\n“It was a beautiful eruption
column16: and lots of people got to see it
column17: and it didn’t take out any major infrastructure and most importantly
column18: it didn’t affect anybody’s life
column19:
” he said at a briefing Tuesday.

Hawaii County Civil Defense Director Talmadge Magno said a one-way route that opened to manage traffic from throngs of people watching the lava would close Thursday.

Magno and other county officials had warned that slow-moving lava could force the closure of Saddle Road
column20: also known as Route 200 or Daniel K. Inouye Highway. That prompted motorists to brace for upheaval from a closure that could add hours to commute times on alternate coastal routes.\n\n“Whatever it is — luck
column21: chance — this is probably the best situation that we could ask for from Mauna Loa
column22: ” Magno said.\n\nFor Native Hawaiians
column23: volcanic eruptions have deep cultural and spiritual significance. During Mauna Loa’s eruption
column24: many Hawaiians took part in cultural traditions
column25: such as singing
column26: chanting and dancing to honor Pele
column27: the deity of volcanoes and fire
column28: and leaving offerings known as “hookupu.”\n\nLava supply to a Mauna Loa fissure ceased on Saturday
column29: the observatory said
column30: and volcanic tremor and earthquakes associated with the eruption “greatly diminished.”\n\n“Spots of incandescence may remain near the vent
column31: along channels
column32: and at the flow front for days or weeks as the lava flows cool
column33: ” the observatory’s activity summary said. “However
column34: eruptive activity is not expected to return based on past eruptive behavior.”\n\nLava supply to Kilauea’s Halemaʻumaʻu lava lake ceased on Friday
column35:
the observatory said: “Potential remains for resumption of this eruption or initiation of a new eruption at or near the summit of Kilauea.”

The observatory will continue monitoring the volcanoes for signs of renewed activity.

Despite the definitive statements
column36: Hon said there’s generally a three-month “cooling off” period before scientists consider the eruption over.\n\nBut there’s been no history of a Mauna Loa rift eruption pausing and restarting
column37: he said
column38: “So we feel pretty confident that this eruption has in fact
column39:
paused and is probably over.”

It was unclear what connection there could be to the volcanoes stopping their eruptions around the same time. The volcanoes can both be seen at the same time from multiple spots in Hawaii Volcanoes National Park near Kilauea’s caldera.

“So
column40: Kilauea may have been diminishing already and the Mauna Loa eruption may have caused enough physical changes to stop it
column41: or it may have just been headed to stop on its own
column42: ” Hon said. “So we don’t have a really good answer for that right now.”\n\nScientists will look at data to study the relationship between the two volcanoes

column6: Scientists at Emory University School of Medicine have identified a new group of compounds that may protect brain cells from inflammation linked to seizures and neurodegenerative diseases.\n\nThe compounds block signals from EP2
column10: says senior author Ray Dingledine
column11: PhD
column12: chairman of Emory's Department of Pharmacology. Anywhere that inflammation is playing a role via EP2
column13: this class of compounds could be useful. Outside the brain
column14: EP2 blockers could find uses in other diseases with a prominent inflammatory component such as cancer and inflammatory bowel disease.\n\nProstaglandins are the targets for non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as aspirin and ibuprofen. NSAIDSs inhibit enzymes known as cyclooxygenases
column15: the starting point for generating prostaglandins in the body. Previous research indicates that drugs that inhibit cyclooxygenases can have harmful side effects. For example
column16: sustained use of aspirin can weaken the stomach lining
column17: coming from prostaglandins' role in the stomach. Even drugs designed to inhibit only cyclooxygenases involved in pain and inflammation
column18: such as Vioxx
column19: have displayed cardiovascular side effects.\n\nDingledine's team's strategy was to bypass cyclooxygenase enzymes and go downstream
column20: focusing on one set of molecules that relay signals from prostaglandins. Working with Yuhong Du in the Emory Chemical Biology Discovery Center
column21: postdoctoral fellows Jianxiong Jiang
column22: Thota Ganesh and colleagues sorted through a library of 262
column23: 000 compounds to find those that could block signals from the EP2 prostaglandin receptor but not related receptors. One of the compounds could prevent damage to neurons in mice after status epilepticus
column24:
a prolonged drug-induced seizure used to model the neurodegeneration linked to epilepsy.

The team found that a family of related compounds had similar protective effects.

Dingledine says that the compounds could become valuable tools for exploring new ways to treat neurological diseases. However
column25: given the many physiological processes prostaglandins regulate
column26: more tests are needed
column27: he says. Prostaglandin E2 is itself a drug used to induce labor in pregnant women
column28: and female mice engineered to lack the EP2 receptor are infertile
column29: so the compounds would need to be tested for effects on reproductive organs

column6: (PhysOrg.com) -- Elderly women with a common gene variant may be more prone to falls
column10: that can cause women to fall.”\n\nFalls are a common and costly problem among older adults. More than a third of people over 65 fall each year

Robert Judson
column14: a PhD student within the University of Aberdeen’s Musculoskeletal Research Group
column15:
was also involved in the research.

He said: “The ACTN3 gene we investigated has already been shown to be important to elite athletes. A study of top Australian power athletes showed that almost all had fully functioning copies of the gene which seems to give one or two per cent more of the muscle power needed by the fastest sprinters and athletes.

“Separate research has also linked the gene with variation in muscle performance in the general population across all age groups.

“This previous research prompted us to look at the clinical implications of the ACTN3 gene. Since strength and power are major contributors to falling in the elderly
column16: we wanted to see if this gene variant was a risk factor for falling.\n\n“Although we have found that to be the case further work is now required to try to find out how the gene variant exactly works and what age group our finding is most relevant to. There is also a need to establish the other potential genetic risk factors for falling.”	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-11 23:42:12

column12: a sports medicine physician at the UNC School of Medicine in Chapel Hill
column13: North Carolina. These pros and cons are
column14: however
column15: different for everyone.\n\nDr. Summerville works with patients to create exercise prescriptions for his patients
column16: and takes a range of factors into account
column17: such as age
column18: function
column19: and mobility
column20: as well as existing health conditions or injuries. Those things all make a difference when it comes to which machine is best for you — as do your specific fitness goals.\n\nAll of these aforementioned cardio machines are designed to improve cardiovascular health
column21: meaning it increases your heart and respiratory rate to strengthen your heart muscle and build endurance. But some also build strength
column22: Summerville says. So
column23: think about what you want out of your workout. Are you there for a strict cardio workout or one that combines cardio and strength
column24: for instance?\n\nAnswering questions like that will help you pick the appropriate machine for you. Also
column25: if you have any disability
column26: injuries
column27: or other health issues that could interfere with your ability to safely exercise — or use one of these machines — talk to your doctor or healthcare provider before starting a new exercise routine.\n\nAnd finally
column28: if you’re going to get your cardio in at the gym using one of these machines
column29: pick one that you like using (so long as you can safely do so). Finding a workout you enjoy doing makes it that much easier to come back to and stick with. After all
column30:
the movement you do (whatever that looks like) is better than some “perfect” workout you don’t do.

Here’s a rundown of some common cardio machines and their specific pros and cons:

What It Is A machine with an endless moving belt for walking or running. “I’d call this the bread-and-butter of cardio machines
column31: ” says Araceli De Leon
column32: an ACE-certified personal trainer and health coach.\n\nMuscles Targeted The treadmill primarily helps build your cardiovascular endurance
column33: says De Leon
column34: but walking or running will also work the lower body muscles
column35: including the quadriceps
column36: glutes
column37: hamstrings
column38: and calves
column39: according to ACSM. It’s not the most effective way to build these muscles
column40: but using the treadmill will help to maintain them
column41: Summerville adds.\n\nPerks You can adjust the speed and incline to increase intensity or perform an interval or HIIT workout
column42: says De Leon. Compared with the elliptical and rower
column43: a treadmill has been found to burn more fat
column44: according to a study published in 2021 in the Journal of Sports Science & Medicine. (It’s worth noting that that study only included nine men and no women.)\n\nConsiderations Being on your phone and looking down or looking up at a TV in the gym can strain your neck
column45: says De Leon. Also
column46: walking too close to the console or holding onto the rails can affect your body’s walking cycle. Try to stay in the middle of the belt and avoid holding on
column47: she says. (If you can’t safely use a treadmill without holding on
column48: then another machine may be a better option. See below.) The treadmill can also be a higher impact activity. Though running or walking on a treadmill is not as hard on the joints as running on concrete
column49: says Summerville
column50: exercising on a track or turf outside will be a more joint-friendly form of exercise.\n\nWhat It Is Indoor or stationary exercise bikes come in a variety of styles
