column6: (AP) -- Mexico's emergence from a national shutdown hit snags as some high schools were not cleaned in time to open and students returned to class in others without swine flu checkups. Cases of the virus popped up in two more Latin America countries.\n\nDespite the hitches
column10: it is possible that a third of the world's population
column11: or about 2 billion people
column12: could become infected if this outbreak turns into a two-year pandemic. Independent experts agreed that the estimate was possible but pointed out that many would not show any symptoms.\n\nIf we do move into a pandemic
column13: then our expectation is that we will see a large number of people infected worldwide
column14: WHO flu chief Keiji Fukuda said Thursday. If you look at past pandemics
column15: it would be a reasonable estimate to say perhaps a third of the world's population would get infected with this virus.\n\nPeople with chronic illnesses are at greatest risk for severe illness from the flu
column16: along with the elderly and young children. So far
column17: most of those with the swine flu in the U. S. and Mexico have been young adults.\n\nWe're still learning about what patients are most at risk
column18: said Dr. Fatima Dawood
column19: a CDC epidemiologist.\n\nWhile Mexican officials insisted the worst was over
column20: authorities in Brazil and Argentina confirmed their first cases of the swine flu
column21: which has now spread to 26 countries
column22: killed 46 people and sickened more than 2
column23: 350 worldwide. Previously
column24: Colombia was the only South American country with a confirmed case.\n\nBrazilian Health Minister Jose Gomes Temporao said three young adults contracted the virus in Mexico
column25: and a fourth in Florida. Only one remains hospitalized and is reported in good condition. Argentina's first swine flu case was a man who returned from Mexico on April 25 and has already been released from hospital.\n\nOn Friday
column26: Hong Kong prepared to lift its weeklong quarantine on the Metropark Hotel
column27: where a Mexican traveler with swine flu stayed last week. About 280 guests and employees are being held inside the building in a measure some have denounced as overreaction.\n\nRestaurants
column28: movie theaters
column29: bars and businesses across Mexico were allowed to open Thursday
column30: and students returned to high schools and universities for the first time in two weeks. Authorities also said fans will be allowed to attend soccer games this weekend
column31: ending a policy that had teams playing in front of empty stadiums.\n\nMexico's government
column32: which raised the death toll to 44
column33: said it was not letting its guard down and that all returning students would be checked for swine flu. It gave an additional $15 million to Mexico's 32 state governments to buy whatever is needed to disinfect classrooms and provided educators with a guide on ways to protect schools from the virus.\n\nBut at a public high school in the southern city of Oaxaca
column34: an Associated Press reporter did not see any returning students wearing masks
column35:
and no doctors or health officials checked people at the door or distributed sanitizing gel.

Orange plastic desk chairs remained covered with grime. Classrooms were packed with as many as 50 students.

They say they washed the floors with soap and water

column37: the classrooms smell bad

column39: a freshman.\n\nUniversities reopened in the southern state of Chiapas
column40: but various high schools in isolated mountain communities remained closed because officials could not disinfect them in time.\n\nAll will open Monday

column46: but it's too much.\n\nJaneth Torres
column47: an industrial engineering student
column48: wore a mask to her university in Ciudad Juarez
column49: but she thought the epidemic was overblown.\n\nIn these times of crisis

column52: 000 doses of the antiviral drug Tamiflu to Mexico as well as 100
column53:
000 protective kits for first responders. U.S. scientists are collaborating with their Mexican counterparts to investigate the outbreak and ways to stem it.

Mexico thanked U. S. officials at a ceremony in Mexico City for their cooperation and aid during the outbreak.

The efficiency and effectiveness with which this emergency has been handled underscores the maturity of relations between the two countries

These COVID-19 fears were often initiated or reinforced by (sometimes excessively) strongly worded risk guidance from the government and physicians:

[Rheumatologist] said

column26: recent data demonstrates only a marginally increased risk
column27: and our study suggests that the health of these patients has been more at risk from the pandemic-related curtailment in their care than from the virus itself. This study corroborates what we as physicians have observed in practice
column28: that unfortunately some of our SARD patients have suffered damage to both their physical and mental health from the reduced care

lupus specialist at Guy's hospital and study co-author.

The importance of feeling medically supported was highlighted by its positive correlation (r=0.44) with overall mental wellbeing scores. Those with pre-existing secure medical relationships often expressed lower anxiety and more confidence that support would be forthcoming if required:

I feel they [GP and rheumatologist] care about me. More so my GP who knows and understands my conditions… When I was in lockdown I knew I could call on him…took away a lot of the stress. (Patient
column31: 70s)\n\nThe move to virtual appointments
column32: whilst necessary in the short-term to reduce risk of infection
column33: is a concern for these patients if continued wide-scale at the expense of regular face-face appointments post-pandemic. SARD patients need to build trusting medical relationships where they feel comfortable reporting their many symptoms
column34: with the previous work from this research team finding that many have been conditioned in healthcare avoidance and under-reporting symptoms due to previous misdiagnoses/dismissive responses.\n\nTests and examinations are also often required to enable prompt and correct treatment

(Patient
column36: 20s)\n\nMost study participants were sympathetic to the huge pandemic-induced pressure the NHS and their physicians were facing
column37: yet also often felt 'abandoned' and that their own care suffered greatly. This study emphasizes the importance of all hospitals/GP surgeries having systems in place to ensure accessible lines of communication for all SARD patients
column38: particularly during times of national and personal health crises

column47: patients and GPs needs to be maintained with clinics available for those with urgent problems and access to routine tests to reduce complications

An editorial by endocrinologists and diabetes specialists published in May 2020 in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism warns that people taking oral corticosteroids like prednisone on a routine basis may be unable to mount a normal stress response to the new coronavirus and are at a high risk of doing poorly if they get COVID-19.

“Corticosteroids may suppress the immune system
column12: which could increase the risk of becoming infected with COVID-19 and also could increase the risk that you could get sicker from the infection
column13: ” says editorial coauthor Ursula Kaiser
column14: MD
column15: chief of the division of endocrinology
column16: diabetes
column17: and hypertension at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.\n\nRaghavendra Mirmira
column18: MD
column19: an editorial coauthor and professor of medicine in the section of endocrinology
column20: diabetes
column21: and metabolism at the University of Chicago
column22: says that the advisory applies to individuals who take prednisone (Deltasone)
column23: hydrocortisone (Hydrocort)
column24: and dexamethasone (Decadron). (Note that corticosteroids are a type of steroid drug
column25: and all of the corticosteroids mentioned belong to a class known as glucocorticoids.)\n\nBased on data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey from 1998 to 2006
column26: an estimated 1 percent of people in the United States take these types of oral corticosteroids. Individuals take them for a range of conditions that are inflammatory by nature
column27: including severe asthma
column28: chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
column29: emphysema
column30: chronic allergies
column31: rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
column32: vasculitis (an inflammation of the blood vessels)
column33: and lupus.\n\nAnother group of people taking oral corticosteroids are those with an adrenal insufficiency disease called Addison’s disease
column34: according to the Mayo Clinic. The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism editorial notes that they also face higher risks regarding COVID-19. Addison’s affects only about 1 in 100
column35: 000 people. With this disease
column36: the adrenal glands
column37: located above each kidney
column38:
are damaged and don't produce enough corticosteroid hormones.

RELATED: What You Need to Know About COVID-19 if You Have Asthma

A corticosteroid works by mimicking cortisol to help the body combat inflammation and stress. The drugs
column39: however
column40: have a dual nature. They can reduce the inflammation that causes things like pain in people with RA and exacerbations in people with severe asthma
column41: but they also lower the immune defenses when taken regularly. This immunosuppression may explain why some people taking oral steroid medications regularly may struggle when they get the virus.\n\n“Chronic steroid therapy can affect the body’s immune system [response] to certain infections
column42: particularly fungus infections and tuberculosis; and it may actually alter the immune system in regard to fighting off certain viruses and bacteria as well
column43: ” says Albert Rizzo
column44: MD
column45: chief medical officer with the American Lung Association.\n\nDr. Mirmira and his coauthors note that people should continue taking their medications as prescribed to keep underlying conditions under control
column46: but Dr. Rizzo emphasizes that the dose makes a difference. “The higher the dose of oral steroids and the longer one takes them
column47: the risk is higher
column48: ” he says. “This means that each patient should discuss trying to get on the lowest dose of oral steroids needed to control the underlying chronic condition to decrease the risks.”\n\nPatients should not lower or taper their doses on their own but should consult with their doctor
column49: according to Rizzo.\n\nIf people taking these medications start to experience COVID-19 symptoms
column50: they may actually need to increase their daily oral corticosteroid dose.\n\n“Those who are taking steroids for long periods of time we assume do not have normal adrenal function
column51: ” says Mirmira. “To compensate for a lack of adrenal function
column52: their dose may have to be increased to respond to the inflammation caused by COVID.”\n\nThe editorial authors recommend if people with known primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency develop symptoms such as a fever and a dry and continuous cough
column53: they should double their oral corticosteroid dose immediately and continue doing so until the fever has subsided. The authors call this a “sick day” rule that many patients should have already been instructed to be following by their doctor. But each patient’s situation is unique
column54:
so only make medication dose changes in response to becoming sick after discussion with your specialist physician (such as an endocrinologist or rheumatologist) or primary care doctor.

Do speak to your medical team if you are on long-term oral corticosteroid therapy to determine a plan for adjusting your dose for this type of situation so that you are prepared if you do get sick.

“Every patient who is on long-term replacement corticosteroid therapy follows ‘sick day’ rules that instruct them to double their dose first if they are sick and then call the doctor
column55: ” says Mirmira. “Increasing the dose of your steroids when you don’t have normal adrenal gland function could save your life
column56: and waiting to talk to a doctor sometimes can be delayed
column57:
and that could make matters worse.”

He adds that in this case there is no downside to doubling the medication in the short term.

And again
column58: the bottom line is that all patients whose doctors have prescribed these daily oral corticosteroid drugs should continue taking them. “Some people might think these medications increase [their] risk of getting infected or increase the severity so [they] should stop taking them
column59: ” says Dr. Kaiser
column60: “but they can get very sick from stopping them
column61: so they should not stop.”\n\nCorticosteroids are also prescribed in inhaled forms and topical solutions that are applied to the skin. These medications
column62: while in the same class as oral corticosteroids
column63: pose fewer complications
column64: according to Mirmira
column65: because they are usually in lower doses and they have less systemic effect in the body. “Drugs taken by mouth have a greater effect in your entire body and are usually in a higher concentration than inhaled or topical corticosteroids
column66: ” Mirmira says.\n\nMany people with asthma
column67: for example
column68: take inhaled corticosteroids because their condition is not severe enough to warrant taking oral medicines.\n\nThese medications include fluticasone propionate (Advair)
column69: mometasone (Asmanex)
column70: ciclesonide (Alvesco)
column71: fluticasone (Flovent)
column73: budesonide and formoterol (Symbicort)
column74: and beclomethasone (Qvar).\n\nMichael Blaiss
column76: the executive medical director of the American College of Allergy
column77: Asthma & Immunology
column78: estimates that between about 1 in 4 and 1 in 5 patients with asthma use regular inhaled medication. Dr. Blaiss adds that while these medications may suppress the immune system to a degree
column79: that effect is relatively mild.\n\n“There is really minimal systemic absorption
column80: and we really don’t have any significant data that the typical doses of inhaled corticosteroids have any major effect on the immune system
column81: ” he says. “When we inhale the corticosteroids
column82: the effect is in the lungs primarily; it doesn’t go throughout the body having an effect.”\n\nAlthough comprehensive research is yet to be done
column83: Blaiss mentions that there is speculation that inhaled steroids could provide some protection from COVID-19. “The reason is that some of the inhaled corticosteroids may decrease the receptor sites found on the cells in the lungs where the virus binds
column84: ” he says.\n\nIf steroid medications might increase the risk of COVID-19
column85: why then can they help some patients who are very sick with COVID-19?\n\nWhile it may sound contradictory
column86: Blaiss says that the drugs do have the potential to be either harmful or helpful when it comes to COVID-19. “Depending on the situation
column87: they can suppress the immune system and make you more vulnerable to the virus or be a treatment
column88: ” he says.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health (NIH)
column89: a combination therapy of corticosteroids and an antiviral agent may reduce symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome (a life-threatening respiratory illness) related to COVID-19. And the NIH strongly recommends the corticosteroid dexamethasone as part of a treatment plan in hospitalized patients who require supplemental oxygen
column90:
with the greatest effect observed in patients who require mechanical ventilation.

The NIH based its advice on a study published in July 2020 in The New England Journal of Medicine that found that hospitalized COVID-19 patients on oxygen support (either mechanical ventilation or oxygen alone) who received 6 milligrams of dexamethasone daily for up to 10 days had reduced mortality within 28 days compared with similar patients not taking the steroid.

Blaiss explains that many people with severe COVID-19 experience a cytokine storm
column91: an overreaction of the immune system
column92: which releases an overabundance of cytokines (chemicals that
column94: can cause hyperinflammation and damage the lungs and other organs)
column95: according to a report published in October 2020 in the journal Clinica Chimica Acta; International Journal of Clinical Chemistry.\n\n“Dexamethasone stays in the system longer than most steroids and blunts the immune system
column96: ” he says.\n\nRemember: Steroid drugs function by dialing down the immune response and reducing inflammation. It’s not necessarily ideal to have the immune response dialed down if you’re counting on it to protect you from the virus that causes COVID-19 or other infections. But if you’re already sick and COVID-19 has ramped up your immune response in an unhealthy way
column97: a steroid drug that can help lessen that response could potentially be helpful

They are set to wrap up a two-day meeting on the issue Friday with international experts at the World Health Organization in Geneva.

column17: but it has made progress - going 21 months before reporting its two most recent deaths in the past month. It has also experienced a burst of poultry outbreaks in 11 provinces nationwide over the same period. Officials have issued fresh warnings for farmers to beef up surveillance
column18: especially since they can no longer rely on the latest poultry vaccine in the north and central aress where it is weak or useless against a new strain that has emerged in the region.\n\nWe have to increase biosecurity
column19: said Thanh
column20: the animal diagnostics director.\n\nThe new strain had earlier been identified in China and was also recently found in Bangladesh and Nepal
column21: where it likely spread via wild birds
column22: said Jan Slingenbergh
column23: a senior animal health officer at the U. N. Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome.\n\nViruses are constantly mutating and require new vaccines to protect against infection - the same reason new human seasonal flu shots are developed each year. A new vaccine is in the works
column24: and scientists have stressed that the new strain has not changed in any way that suggests the virus is becoming more dangerous.\n\nThe U. N. agriculture agency warned of a possible resurgence in bird flu outbreaks after the new strain was identified
column25: potentially increasing risk to humans. However
column26: Vietnam's two recent deaths occurred in the southern Mekong Delta
column27: where the vaccine remains effective. WHO stressed it is also normal to see a spike in cases and poultry outbreaks during this time of year.\n\nWHO has always said that as long as the virus is entrenched in poultry
column28: which it is
column29: there continues to be the risk of bird-to-human transmission
column30: spokesman Gregory Hartl said in Geneva. That risk means that you cannot predict exactly if the transmission will happen and if it will be regular
column31: but there is the risk so that's why it's not surprising to see cases.\n\nVietnam buys most of its poultry vaccine from China
column32: which has continued with its robust vaccination campaign of some 15 billion doses despite the emergence of the new strain. Researchers there have developed a new version that works against the strain
column33: but it's unclear when it might be ready for distribution
column34: said Keith Hamilton
column35: an animal influenza expert at the Paris-based World Organization of Animal Health.\n\nWe emphasize that vaccination is a complementary tool
column36: he said. It has to be used in conjunction with other control measures - biosecurity on farms
column37: early detection is essential
column38: so is a rapid response to contain and eliminate sources of disease.\n\nBut in Ha Nam province
column39: on the outskirts of Vietnam's capital
column40: Hanoi
column41: animal health officials are desperate to contain a poultry outbreak that hit last week. They have ordered 1 million doses of vaccine
column42: hoping it will provide at least some protection.\n\nI wish to have an effective vaccine against bird flu as soon as possible
column43: so I can go on raising ducks
column44: said farmer Nguyen Van Duong
column45: whose entire flock was slaughtered after the virus was detected.\n\nI am devastated at losing my investment on the ducks
column46: but we will do anything to work with the authorities to stop it from spreading. The last thing we want is an outbreak to happen again.\n\n©2012 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published

Only 20 percent of children with persistent asthma have a level of control that is optimal
column10: in contrast
column11: current therapies are very effective. In fact
column12: according to reports issued by the National Institutes of Health
column13: if used consistently and in conjunction with action plans and avoidance of environmental triggers
column14: the therapies should ideally make it possible for children to experience no symptoms of asthma
column15: no limitation in function and no serious exacerbations.\n\nThat's a lofty goal to dangle before patients
column16: Halterman said. We wanted a closer look into why so many children weren't reaping the benefits of today's therapeutic advances.\n\nCurrent guidelines recommend that all children with persistent asthma – half of the 9.4 percent of children who have any form of asthma – are prescribed daily anti-inflammatory medication. In spite of this
column17: the most recent study revealed that 37 percent received no preventive medication
column18: and perhaps more shockingly
column19: 43 percent did receive medications
column20: yet they were still troubled by poor symptom control (experiencing either persistent symptoms or frequent asthma attacks).\n\nThis second group – the children who were experiencing poor symptom control despite the use of preventive medications – has received relatively little attention until now
column21: Halterman said.\n\nEspecially interested in this disconnect
column22: Halterman and her colleagues began to examine the data and found several potential reasons for it
column23: including children not using the daily medication consistently
column24: being exposed to environmental triggers
column25: such as secondhand smoke
column26: or allergens like mold or pets
column27: or simply not receiving adequate education about what to watch out for or what to do in the case of an attack.\n\nEven more surprisingly
column28: this incidence of poor control despite medication use was prevalent across the board
column29: regardless of the child's age or the household's income level.\n\nThe bottom line is that there's much work that needs to be done in making sure that children with asthma receive appropriate and effective care; it's more complex than one might think
column30: Halterman said. Asthma care involves coordination on everyone's part. Parents and patients need to report and track symptoms
column31: relay this information to their doctor
column32: use medications as prescribed
column33: and steer clear of triggers. Physicians need to recognize persistent symptoms in their patients
column34: and take time to prescribe
column35: educate and draw up unique action plan for each patient's management.	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-11 22:25:37

Who you meet can be as exciting as what you see during the Emirates Airline Festival of Literature in Dubai.\n\nLast March marked the Emirates’ sixth annual celebration of the written word with writers from all over the world flying in to participate in a week of scheduled events. Popular fiction writers
column10: and amuse enthusiastic audiences.\n\nWant advice on trendy topics for that bestseller you’ve been contemplating? Need to know how to get it published after it’s finished? The wordsmiths at the Festival of Literature will tell you in a dozen easy steps. As a special bonus
column11: you can explore the wonderful world of ski slopes
column12: sand dunes
column13: and Arabian souks just outside the window.\n\nThe home of the festival
column14: Dubai
column15: is an amazing place
column16: an Emerald City that soars in jagged high-rise spires out of a desert that just a generation ago housed a few coral block buildings and some roaming camels. Fishing dhows with lateen rigs still sail up and down Dubai Creek as they have for millennia
column17: but instead of Indian traders and Persian merchants clustering their wharves
column18: skyscrapers
column19: hallmarked by the world’s tallest building
column20: form walls of glass and steel behind them.\n\nAt the edge of this surreal scene
column21: a celebration of books seems somehow right. Dubai’s Festival of Literature is the brainchild of British-born Isobel Abdulhoul
column22: who came here as a bride in 1968.\n\nDuring the festival
column23: I met with Abdulhoul at a lunch prepared by chef and cookbook author Greg Malouf. Over grilled quail
column24: homemade laban cheese
column25: and fresh sesame bread
column26: she told me that when she came to Dubai the only books she had were those she'd brought with her.\n\n“I read them over and over and over and when I couldn’t find anymore
column27: I opened Dubai’s first book store
column28: ” she said. It was Abdulhoul’s love of books that led her to launch the festival.\n\nThis year over 8
column29: 000 visitors arrived in Dubai City to hear 170 authors discuss their work
column30: autograph their latest creations
column31: and talk about the world of literature. InterContinental Festival City
column32: the hotel complex where the festival was held
column33: was jammed with a milling sea of literature enthusiasts who roamed the centre and spilled out around outdoor food stands
column34: shawarma stalls
column35:
and performance areas where stand-up comedians traded off with drum-thumping rock bands.

In the halls and corridors there were tables of books everywhere you looked. It was my first year at the festival and the family-friendly event offered some of my favourite children’s authors and historical fiction writers signing their works and chatting about creativity. Would I see best-selling British author Rachel Hore? Would I be able to talk with her? The answer to both questions turned out to be yes.

To celebrate the festival’s opening
column36: an evening event called Desert Stanzas was planned out in the distant dunes. I travelled for an hour by minibus and then took a 4-wheel drive over shadowed sands to what at first appeared to be a brilliantly lit mirage
column37: an oasis of tents and camels and oriental carpets rising spectacularly from a shallow bowl in the desert.\n\nWe were greeted by rows of dancing men in long white traditional robes and lavishly dressed children who poured rosewater over our hands out of silver ewers. An Arabian buffet of exotic food
column38: hot off of glowing coals
column39: was set between the long lines of open tents where tables and cushions had been arranged.\n\nAs we ate
column40: we listened to poets from different cultures read their works; Andrew Motion
column41: Britain’s former poet laureate
column42: headlined the event. Celebrated Arab poet Khalid Albudoor gave a dramatic reading to the accompanying music of an Arabian oud
column43: referring to his poetry as “melodies of travelling Bedouins.”\n\nThat night
column44: I learned that poetry is the language of the nomad recited in the evening around the campfire. “It doesn’t matter if you understand it
column45: ” German poet Frank Klötgen later told us
column46: “try to feel it.” In that setting
column47: it wasn’t difficult.\n\nFor the Arabs of the Gulf
column48: the beginning is the word and the word is everywhere you look. As in the Far East
column49: calligraphy is a highly rated art
column50: so the next day I made a pilgrimage to one of Dubai’s greatest calligraphers
column51: Iranian-born Amir Hossein.\n\nHis shop
column52: The Golden Pen
column53: is a tiny place in the Moroccan quarter of a western-style mall. Western classical music wafted me into an Aladdin’s cave crammed with treasures. Hossein is a restless artist always trying to push boundaries. He showed me a sewing needle
column54: the smallest that he could find in the souk (open-air marketplace)
column55: and on the all but invisible head he had engraved the word “Allah.” The work was so tiny he had had to invent an entire toolkit to create it.\n\nIn his shop vault he kept the opalescent nacre of a mollusk shell on which he had engraved the first 55 pages of the Koran. Its matching engraved bivalve had been a gift to the son of Dubai’s ruler. “The two pieces represent friendship
column56: ” said Hossein
column57: holding the fragile shell to the light. It was so translucent that I could see his hand through it. As another gesture of friendship
column58: he drew my name in Arabic calligraphy in handmade walnut ink with a sharpened stick of bamboo and made me a present of it.\n\nFor something completely different the next day
column59: I went to a panel of bestselling murder mystery writers. South African Deon Meyer shared the stage with British authors Simon Kernick and Peter James
column60: and Swedish best-selling author Camilla Läckberg. How did they think up their stories? Did they always know who the killer would be?\n\nSounds like Peter James gets much of his material riding around with the police of Brighton. “No one
column61: ” he told us
column62: “knows more of life than a 30-year career cop.” James plots his works in detail (you could almost see the flow charts) while Läckberg likes to let things evolve.\n\n“You need an idea
column63: a character
column64: and an ending
column65: ” advised the woman whose first work of fiction written at the age of four was the murder of Mrs. Santa Claus.\n\nOne thing the festival is particularly good at is arranging evening events (open to the public) to complement the day’s panels. Following the murder mystery panel
column66: I went off to the Murder Mystery Dinner with a dimly-lit ballroom full of other mystery aficionados. The theme of the festival was Metamorphosis
column67: and the Dubai Drama Group had prepared to perform a play entitled “A Modern Metamorphosis.”\n\nOver tuna tartare and beef tenderloin
column68: we watched the actors create characters whose dialogue revealed hidden lives and secret yearnings. Who would die and who would be called out as the wily assassin? Each dinner table was asked to form a team
column69: question the suspects
column70: and then write down the identity of the suspected perpetrator. We called our table team “Medea
column71: ” a suitably sinister name for a group of hot shot amateur detectives who in the end managed to guess the identity of the villain.\n\nOn the last day of the festival
column72: travel writer and panelist Tim Mackintosh-Smith quoted the words of a much earlier traveller
column73: Ibn Battuta: “Time does not flow with the same speed in every place.”\n\nOutside
column74: along Dubai Creek
column75: an estuary flowing inward rather than outward to the sea
column76: dhow builders were slowly fashioning the carapaces of boats whose antique design was buried in the past
column77: while a mile away frantic crews of builders threw up skyscraper after skyscraper in a race to the future.\n\nAt The Golden Pen
column78: Amir Hossein painstakingly drew a flourish of complex calligraphy with ancient roots
column79: while all around me authors cranked out books so quickly their publishers could scarcely keep up. As a fitting finale to my literary adventures
column80: I took a taxi to look at the Persian Gulf. Scholars and poets had written about it. Merchants and travellers had sailed across it. I'd read about it
column82: and there it was
column84:
beyond a wide swath of sand.

The end of the beginning or the beginning of the end? In Dubai only time would tell.

Susan James is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. She has lived in India

column6: As Shen Yun Performing Arts continues its world tour showcasing the lost traditions of ancient China
column10: and its essence was continuously passed down for 5
column11: 000 years. But the rise of communism in China had a devastating effect on the Middle Kingdom’s ancient culture and traditions.\n\nFrom the beginning
column12: the Chinese Communist Party’s (CCP) plan to “revolutionize” Chinese culture was in fact an attempt to destroy its spirit completely.\n\nThe traditional Chinese culture sought harmony between man and the universe and emphasized ethics and morality. It was based on the faiths of Confucianism
column13: Buddhism
column14: and Taoism and embodied honesty
column15: kindness
column16: harmony
column17: and tolerance.\n\nThese principles and the social standards set by Confucius’s five cardinal virtues of benevolence
column18: righteousness
column19: propriety
column20: wisdom
column21:
and faithfulness were anathema to the CCP’s policy of atheism.

The CCP had an inherent ideological opposition to traditional Chinese culture—which believes in gods and a heavenly mandate—and made the culture an enemy in an effort to bolster its own control.

Soon after the CCP came into power in 1949
column22: it began to destroy churches and temples
column23: burn scriptures
column24: and force Buddhist monks and nuns to return to secular life. By the 1960s
column25: there were hardly any religious places left in China.\n\nMao Zedong’s Great Cultural Revolution
column26: which began in 1966
column27: brought even greater religious and cultural catastrophe with its campaign of “Casting Away the Four Olds”: old ideas
column28: old culture
column29: old customs
column30: and old habits.\n\nBuddhist and Taoist temples
column31: historical and scenic sites
column32: calligraphy
column33: paintings
column34: and antiques became the main targets for destruction by the Red Guards. Many one-of-a-kind books
column35: calligraphy works
column36: and paintings that had been collected by intellectuals were burned or shredded into pulp.\n\nWriter Qin Mu (1919–1992) described the Cultural Revolution in bleak terms: “It was truly an unprecedented calamity. [The CCP] imprisoned millions due to their association with a [targeted] family member
column37: ended the lives of millions more
column38: shattered families
column39: turned children into hoodlums and villains
column40: burned books
column41: tore down ancient buildings
column42: and destroyed ancient intellectuals’ gravesites
column43: committing all kinds of crimes in the name of revolution.”\n\nIn this way
column44: the dignity and sacredness of religion and culture was annihilated
column45: as was people’s spiritual identity formed by faith and culture. Many lost their moral bearings and became indoctrinated with the CCP’s own set of standards
column46: such as class struggle
column47: inciting hatred and violence
column48: self-criticism
column49: and “fighting with heaven and earth.”\n\nThis “Party culture
column50: ” which has at its heart despotism and dictatorship
column51: was established through continuous political movements and was promoted by the CCP as a continuation of traditional Chinese culture.\n\nAfter the Party adopted economic reform and an open-door policy
column52: it renovated many churches as well as Buddhist and Taoist temples. Throughout China
column53: temple fairs
column54: art and calligraphy exhibits
column55: culture festivals with dragon and lion dances
column56: and New Year galas were staged.\n\nThis
column57: however
column58: simply restored the superficial appearance of the culture. The essence of China’s profound culture had by then been well and truly gutted.	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-11 21:20:37

How should I apply a roller bandage to a wound?

Secure the end of the bandage in place with a turn of the bandage. Wrap the bandage around the body part until the dressing is completely covered and the bandage extends several inches beyond the dressing. Tie or tape the bandage in place.

column6: Technology used in video games is making its way to hospital rooms
column10: we thought much of what we learned regarding older people could apply to protecting hospital patients.\n\nFalls can happen anywhere
column11: but in hospitals people are at higher risk of falls because patients are sick or injured
column12: in an unfamiliar place and sometimes dizzy from medication. Because hospital patients are often elderly or have underlying health conditions
column13: they also are at higher risk for injuries if they fall.\n\nTechnology that quickly detects falls and alerts health professionals can improve patient care and help in the diagnosis of injuries
column14: said Rantz. Also
column15: technology that captures data on patient falls can help health professionals learn about risk factors for falls
column16: which could help create more effective ways of preventing them.\n\nDuring the past several years
column17: the team has explored a variety of technologies in its work with senior citizens
column18: including Doppler radar
column19: sound sensors and video cameras
column20: said Marjorie Skubic
column21: PhD
column22: the LaPierre Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering and a professor of computer science at the MU College of Engineering. Doppler radar and sound sensors can both detect that a person fell
column23: but neither shows what happened leading up to the fall
column24: Skubic said.\n\nBy seeing what happened before a fall
column25: we can better understand what caused it
column26: Rantz said. The more we know about what causes falls
column27: the more effectively we can prevent them.\n\nOrdinary video cameras record the events before a fall
column28: but they work only when there's enough light
column29: said Skubic
column30: who also serves as the director of MU's Center for Eldercare and Rehabilitation Technology.\n\nWhen video-game motion-capture technology was released a few years ago
column31: the MU team gained a new tool
column32: one that avoided the limitations of the other technologies and could monitor falls in a different way. And unlike video cameras
column33: the motion-capture system portrays people as anonymous
column34: three-dimensional silhouettes
column35: protecting their privacy. Those are a few of the reasons that Skubic called the motion-capture technology a game changer.\n\nThe device looks like a thin black box. On one side
column36: black glass covers the sensors that pick up the movements of video-game players—or of patients in a hospital room. One sensor
column37: a depth camera
column38: measures the distances to objects in its view. A cord connects the black box to a small computer.\n\nThe system works by sending a grid pattern of infrared light
column39: invisible to the human eye
column40: into a room
column41: and then examining how objects and persons in the room distort the pattern. The machine analyzes these distortions to make a 3-D map
column42: showing a patient
column43: her bed and tray table
column44: and everything else in the room.\n\nIf the system detects a person on the floor
column45: it automatically reviews the preceding events as the person moved to the floor. Does the movement represent a fall
column46: or a person kneeling to tie a shoe lace? Applying a precise algorithm created by Skubic
column47: doctoral graduate Erik Stone and an interdisciplinary team
column48: the computer calculates the probability that the changes represent a person's fall.\n\nIn the study
column49: the MU research team installed a motion-capture device in each of six patient rooms at University Hospital in Columbia
column50: Mo. The hospital is part of the MU Health System
column51: an academic medical center that includes the MU School of Medicine
column52: the MU Sinclair School of Nursing and the MU School of Health Professions. The researchers trained nursing staff to explain the study to patients. The devices collected data continuously
column53: monitoring the rooms 24 hours a day.\n\nThe research article covers the first eight months of the study. During that time
column54: the sensors did not record any patient falls
column55: but stunt actors simulated 50 falls in the rooms
column56: providing more data for the algorithm.\n\nWe believe the technology is promising because it accurately identified falls and may eventually help prevent falls
column57: said Rantz
column58:
who also serves as a Helen E. Nahm Chair with the MU Sinclair School of Nursing and the University of Missouri Curators' Professor. We are now in the process of installing the sensors in more patient rooms to learn more about its effectiveness.

The researchers felt that one potentially encouraging aspect of their work was the reduction of falls in the six patient rooms during the study.

I think these devices may have brought more attention to the issue of falls
column59: Skubic said. It could have made patients more aware of the risks and more likely to ask their nurses for help getting out of bed.	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-12 01:17:40

column6: Anala is a gender-neutral name with roots in the Hindu culture and heritage. This Sanskrit-origin name implies ‘fire’ or ‘fiery.’ The name is used for baby girls
column10: was married to Marichi
column11: sage Kashyapa’s son. Another version of Anala is in Chapter 66 of the Ādi Parva
column12: in the great epic Mahābhārata. Here
column13:
she is the great-granddaughter of Krodhavaśā and the daughter of Dakṣha. Analā is the wife of the sage Kashyapa in this version.

Its appeal seems to have crossed the Indian subcontinent as foreign authors have used it in their works of fiction. One such example is the book Anala – A Well-lived Life by Michael Loucks. It’s a long 1563-page book and falls in the romance genre.

column6: Neutron stars – the dead stellar remnants of old
column11: to be precise). We know the rotational period of this star to 15 decimal places
column12: making it truly one of the most accurate clocks in the universe.But
column13: as we show in a paper published today in the journal Science
column14: it was not supposed to be this way. Gravitational waves from all of the black holes in the universe were supposed to ruin the timing precision of this pulsar. But they have not.\n\nGravitational waves stretch and squeeze space
column15: causing the distance between us and the neutron star to change. The gravitational waves we were looking for should have altered that distance by about ten metres
column16: a tiny fraction given that this neutron star is about 3.6 x 1019 metres from Earth (that’s 3.6 with 19 zeros following)! But this should have been enough to show up in our measurements. Yet the fact that our measurements are so accurate tells us that something is wrong with the theory. This doesn’t mean that gravitational waves don’t exist. There are other facets of our understanding of the universe that might be off track.Whatever the resolution to this quandary
column17: it is sure to change the way we understand the most massive black holes in the universe.The centre of our galaxy harbours a black hole that weighs more than four million times the mass of our sun. But this is a lightweight; other galaxies contain black holes weighing more than 17 billion times the mass of our Sun.\n\nAnd we have good reason to believe that most
column18: if not all
column19: galaxies contain supermassive black holes in their cores. We also know that galaxies throughout the universe grow by merging with one another. Following the merger of any two galaxies
column20: the two black holes from the parent galaxies sink to the centre of the daughter galaxy
column21: forming a supermassive black hole binary pair. At some point
column22: the subsequent evolution of the binary pair becomes dominated by the emission of gravitational waves.\n\nGravitational waves are tiny ripples in the fabric of spacetime
column23: and are a direct consequence of Albert Einstein’s theory of general relativity. We celebrate its 100th birthday in November this year. When any two black holes are spiralling around one another
column24: they ought to emit gravitational waves. These carry energy away from the system
column25: causing the two black holes to move closer together.The sum of all the binary supermassive black holes in the universe should produce a background of gravitational waves (similar to the cosmic microwave background). It is this background that was expected to ruin our precision timing of PSR J1909-3744.Astrophysicists have made a number of predictions about the strength of the background. These predictions incorporate state-of-the-art measurements of galaxy formation and evolution
column26: and the most sophisticated theoretical models of how the universe evolves following the Big Bang.But we want to be very clear that our lack of a detection does not imply that Einstein’s theory of relativity is wrong
column27: nor does it imply that gravitational waves don’t exist. While we don’t know the real solution
column28: we have a number of ideas.Perhaps not every galaxy in the universe contains a supermassive black hole. Reducing the fraction of galaxies that host supermassive black holes in the models reduces the predicted amplitude of the gravitational wave background
column29: potentially making it undetectable by our observations.\n\nPerhaps we do not understand the relationship between the mass of the host galaxy and the mass of the black hole. We use empirical relationships between galaxy and black hole masses to determine the latter. While we believe these are robust in the local universe
column30: the black hole mergers we are most sensitive to occur billions of light years from us
column31: where our understanding of these empirical relations is far from complete. Perhaps one of our assumptions about the process that drives the mergers is too simplistic. For example
column32: if the centres of galaxies contain significant amounts of gas
column33: it can act like an extra friction force
column34: causing black holes to merge with one another quicker than expected. This would also cause a smaller-than-expected amplitude of the gravitational wave background.At the moment
column35: each of these scenarios is equally plausible. Continued observations of pulsars
column36: as well as observations of the distant universe with large optical telescopes
column37: may soon allow us to distinguish between these ideas. And
column38: one day
column39: we may finally find the direct evidence for the existence of gravitational waves that we’re looking for.Paul Lasky
column40: Postdoctoral Fellow in Gravitational Wave Astrophysics
column41: Monash University and Ryan Shannon
column42: Research Fellow
column43: International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research
column44: Curtin University

WAYS TO HELP YOUR EYES

To keep your eyes healthy

A leading testing expert says DNA genotype testing is revealing how most of us have a little Neanderthal in our blood
column10: Modern humans like ourselves only reached the British Isles around 40
column11: 000 years ago and
column12: because of the impact of the last ice age
column13: Britain was only continually settled around 12
column14: 000 years ago. Much of our DNA dates back much further than this
column15: meaning our origins can be traced back to places far beyond Britain.\n\nThe journey that each of our ancestors took may be very different from that of our friends' and neighbors' ancestors
column16: however
column17: and these different migratory paths
column18: from thousands of years ago
column19: are still captured and represented in our blood.\n\nFascinatingly
column20: the majority of Brits have a small amount of genetic material from humans who actually arrived here far earlier than modern man. Genetic testing reveals that people of European or Asian backgrounds have around 2% Neanderthal DNA
column21: with some individuals having even more. People of African descent
column22: in contrast
column23: are likely to have far less
column24: around 0.3%.\n\nNeanderthals evolved in Europe and Asia while modern humans—our species
column25: Homo sapiens—were evolving in Africa. Modern humans migrating into Europe are now thought to have met and interbred with Neanderthals. Those of us with a percentage of Neanderthal in our DNA share some genes with Britain's earliest colonizers.\n\nEarly humans may have arrived in Britain as long as 950
column26: 000 years ago. We know Neanderthals had arrived here 400
column27: 000 years ago thanks to the discovery of the skull of a young woman in Swanscombe
column28: Kent. The National History Museum says these early humans probably traveled across the vast prairies of ancient Britain following herds of large animals
column29: such as mammoths
column30: to seasonal hunting grounds.\n\nIt used to be thought that Neanderthals and modern humans shared no genetic makeup and that modern humans may have even killed off the Neanderthals. However
column31: more recent research has shown that modern humans overlapped with Neanderthal populations for a period.\n\nA paper published in Nature in 2014 traced the complete genome sequence of a Neanderthal woman from the Altai Mountains in Siberia. It found evidence of inbreeding
column32: possibly as small groups became isolated due to factors such as climate change. This could have hurried their extinction.\n\nIt's not only the distant origins of mankind that can be mapped using modern genotesting. DNA testing tells us about the migration patterns of both our paternal and maternal lines
column33: based on our genetics. Genotyping charts a migration map
column34: tracing the maternal and paternal lineage through DNA haplogroups (groups that share a common ancestor).\n\nSome of the information contained within our Ancestry Information Markers can also link us with modern populations today. For example
column35: London Medical Laboratory's new DNA Genotype Profile test compares our genetic profile with reference datasets of 150+ populations
column36: based around 37 clusters in different continents and regions. The test reveals the proportion of various modern populations recorded within our own individual genetic makeup. For example
column37: the test may indicate that our ancestry is approximately 50% African
column38: 25% European
column39: 20% Asian
column40: and 5% unknown.\n\nTaking a test can reveal some fascinating insights into our ancestry
column41: sometimes revealing surprises along the way. In the future
column42: it could also have a more practical medical application. It's possible that variations in our DNA may influence the risk of developing certain diseases. As we study more about our ancestors and their genetic makeup
column43: we may be able to build up patterns of disease risk.\n\nTo find out what secrets your DNA holds about your ancestral lineage is surprisingly easy. London Medical Laboratory's simple saliva test can be taken at home or through the post
column44: or at one of the many drop-in clinics that offer it across London and nationwide in over 95 selected pharmacies and health stores.	P	2024-02-11 21:10:33	2024-02-11 21:11:34

column6: Disclosure: This post may contain affiliate links. This easy blueberry crumb cake is deliciously simple. The light and fluffy cake is packed with juicy blueberries and loaded with cinnamon crumble. Enjoy a slice of this homemade cake for breakfast or dessert with coffee. Find this recipe and more on my blog HERE:  https://sugarylogic.com/easy-blueberry-crumb-cake/\n\nThere is nothing like a fluffy
column10: and cinnamon. Pour in the melted butter and stir until everything has combined and crumbles. Refrigerate the crumb topping until it is needed.PREP THE BLUEBERRIES - Toss the blueberries in a tablespoon of flour until coated
column11: and set aside.\n\nMAKE THE CAKE - Mix the dry ingredients in a separate bowl. In a large mixing bowl
column12: beat the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Add the eggs
column13: one at a time
column14: beating well after each addition. Stir in the vanilla extract. Alternately add the dry ingredients and the sour cream
column15: starting and ending with the dry
column16: and mix until combined. Fold in the blueberries. BAKE - Pour the cake batter into a greased and lined 8x8-inch baking pan. Cover with the streusel and bake.Swap the sour cream for Greek yogurt or buttermilk.Add one to two teaspoons of lemon juice and a tablespoon of lemon zest to the batter for a lemon blueberry cake.Store this cake in an airtight container or keep it in its pan and tightly wrap the top with foil. This blueberry crumb cake can be left at room temperature for two to three days or in the refrigerator for up to five days.\n\nUse room temperature ingredients (eggs and butter) for the best incorporation and a smooth batter. Chill the streusel until you are ready to use it - this keeps the butter cold until it hits the oven.Toss the blueberries in flour before adding them to the cake batter to keep them from sinking to the bottom of the cake.Grease and line the baking pan with parchment paper to prevent sticking. The parchment paper also makes it easy to remove the cake from the pan for easy slicing.Serve the cake while still subtly warm for the best flavor experience.Can you use frozen blueberries in crumb cake?You can use frozen berries in this recipe. Use them straight from the freezer
column17: do not thaw them out first. Do still toss the frozen berries in the extra tablespoon of flour.Can you freeze blueberry crumb cake?Yes

column10: and introspection.For a nation that appears to have produced the worst possible results—a fuzzy presidential election

column12: and a highly mobilized African American population who saw their dreams of political attention dashed—the struggle to understand the election will be equally divisive and unrewarding.The major problem with the fall 2020 election is that nothing appears to have worked right
column13: sowing the seeds of political dissatisfaction that could resonate for years if not decades. Here are a variety of ways in which the U.S. political system suffered near total organ failure.The U.S. electorate begged for real policy in 2020

column36: in particular
column37: neither leads
column38: reflects
column39: nor influences the public will in the United States.For the second U.S. election in a row

column47: in contrast

column49: however

The failure of big money may convince millions of small donors to stop responding to the endless stream of fundraising emails.Many people made millions of dollars off electoral processes that
column55: in the end

column60: musicians

column63: and by lining up so strongly against almost half the American electorate
column64: they have managed to politicize popular culture and professional sports in a way that will resonate for years.The 2020 strategy emphasized political ridicule at a remarkable level. President Trump dumped endless scorn on former Vice President Biden
column65: but almost half of all American voters didn’t reject the Democratic candidate on account of the harsh comments. Biden
column66: in turn

column68: again

column70: as the president’s share of the popular vote suggests. This applies to the media as well. The anti-Trump contempt of virtually all TV comedians would

column73: but the attacks clearly didn’t sway the election.Since the election of Donald Trump in 2016

column79: and human sexuality

column86: the political needle in the United States barely budged. While Trump and Republicans railed against the perceived left-wing bias in the academy
column87: ironically it appears that they over-estimated the influence and impact of academic interventions.The two main parties—the Democrats and the Republicans—used to be the foundations of American political stability. They varied little in substantive policies

column89: and provided a counterbalance to the aspirations of presidents

column93: united temporarily by a hatred for President Trump. The Republican desire to hold on to power caused many key leaders to surrender their independence to Donald Trump.Instead of being a source for constructive ideas and political moderation
column94: the parties have become ideological battlegrounds (the Democrats) or facilitators of a strong leader (the GOP). It’s not clear that they’re deeply connected with the American people
column95: and they don’t appear to be outlets for any electoral aspirations other than self-interest.Through 2019–2020
column96: the U.S. election was going to be about the political redemption of African Americans. This was the first test of Black Lives Matter and came in the wake of countless public attestations that animosity toward African Americans had been relegated to the past. African Americans mobilized around the call to action—led by professional athletes

column102: it was really all for naught. Almost half of the American electorate chose not to rebuke a president who apparently stood in the way of the improvement of life opportunities for African Americans. It’s hard not imagine a withdrawal of African Americans from electoral politics and a growing sense of dissatisfaction with the American status quo.The United States has one of the strangest national electoral systems in the world. Put aside the unusual Electoral College system and consider instead the absence of a national electoral system. Focus on the fact that counties
column103: not states and not the U.S. government
column104: run elections. The 2020 election was the culmination of thousands of local-level electoral processes. The complex web of rules
column107: and management styles creates confusion and uncertainty. It’s hardly a top-flight demonstration of a democratic election
column108: and it’s revealed structural weaknesses in U.S. politics.In the Bush–Gore election of 2000
column109: the crucial decision was made not in the ballot box but by the Supreme Court. In the ultra-tight 2020 election
column110: and with Trump and his supporters demanding judicial protection
column111: the courts will once again likely provide for a continuation of the campaign into the coming weeks.With President Trump having filled many of the nation’s courtrooms with Republican-friendly judges
column112: the assumption is that the courts could provide the GOP candidate with further support. To the degree that this is tested—and true—it’s a degradation of the credibility and integrity of the legal system in the United States.There’s probably too much to hope that the United States will wake up
column114: and alter the controversial processes that lie ahead. As the country stares into the black hole of presidential uncertainty
column115: and with the Republicans narrowly holding the Senate
column116: the political quagmire of 2020 is certain to spread into 2021 and beyond.The United States suffered a system breakdown in November 2020 that brought to the surface the vulnerabilities and shortcomings of a deeply flawed political structure. Uncertainty reigns supreme
column117: and prospects for greater political chaos

column10: of the University of Utah School of Medicine

column12: and colleagues conducted a study to evaluate the development and content of DCD policies at children's hospitals and evaluate variation among policies
column13: which were collected between November 2007 and January 2008 from hospitals in the United States
column14: Puerto Rico
column15: and Canada. Of inquiries to 124 children's hospitals
column16: a response was received from 105 (85 percent). Of these respondents
column17: 72 percent had DCD policies
column18: 19 percent were developing policies
column19: and 7 percent neither had nor were developing policies.\n\nThe researchers received and analyzed 73 approved policies. Sixty-one (84 percent) specify criteria or tests for declaring death
column20: including electrocardiogram (ECG) findings
column21: pulselessness
column22: apnea
column23: and unresponsiveness. Four policies require total waiting periods prior to organ recovery at variance with professional guidelines: 1 less than 2 minutes and 3 longer than 5 minutes. Sixty-four policies (88 percent) preclude transplant personnel from declaring death and 51 percent prohibit them from involvement in premortem (taking place immediately before death) management.\n\nWhile 65 policies (89 percent) indicate the importance of palliative care

(HealthDay)—Tighter U. S. government restrictions on prescription painkillers containing hydrocodone led to reduced use of opioid medications such as Vicodin
column10: San Diego Health.\n\nWe wanted to see how the legislation has impacted laboratory drug testing
column11: said Joshua Akin
column12: a clinical laboratory scientist.\n\nAkin and his colleagues compared nearly 254
column13: 000 urine drug test results from UC San Diego Health for 18 months before and 18 months after the DEA reclassification. They found that positive results for hydrocodone fell nearly 3 percent and positive opioid screening results decreased 0.09 percent over that time.\n\nThe findings could help guide efforts to combat the opioid addiction crisis in the United States
column14: the researchers said.\n\nThe results suggest that reclassification reduced hydrocodone use by decreasing prescriptions for the drug. Also
column15: it appears that tightening prescription practices for other opioids could help fight the current opioid abuse epidemic
column16: the researchers noted.\n\nThe study was to be presented Tuesday at the annual meeting of the American Association for Clinical Chemistry
column17: in San Diego. Data and conclusions presented at meetings are usually considered preliminary until published in a peer-reviewed medical journal.\n\nIt's hard to make conclusions based on prescription data alone—sometimes patients aren't taking their medication as prescribed or are using drugs illicitly. The beauty of laboratory data is that you can't really deny the test results
column18: Akin said in an association news release.\n\nStill
column19: the opioid crisis is far from over. More than one out of three average Americans used a prescription opioid painkiller in 2015

(Medical Xpress)—A new tool developed by scientists at The Methodist Hospital separates tumor-causing cancer cells from more benign cells by subjecting the cells to a microscopic game of Plinko—except only the squishiest cells make it through.\n\nAs reported in this week's Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (early edition online)
column10: the project's principal investigator. The throughput of a MS-Chip is at the level of one million cells. When a stiff cell blocks one particular barrier
column11:
many other bypasses will allow flexible cells to flow through.

Cancer stem cells are known to be squishier than other cancer cells. The team of scientists showed that flexible cells separated by the MS-Chip exhibited gene expression patterns consistent with cancer stem cells.

Many papers indicate the presence of cancer stem cells means a worse prognosis for patients
column12: said cancer scientist Jenny Chang
column13: M. D.
column14:
co-principal investigator and director of Methodist's Cancer Center. Yet they are not typically quantified by doctors.

Subsequent analysis of separated cells by the Methodist and MD Anderson team showed the flexible cells were less likely to express cell cytoskeleton genes and more likely to express the motility genes that could contribute to metastasis.

By testing for the presence of metastatic cells
column15: doctors may be able to tell whether cancer treatment was successful
column16: or an as-yet untreated cancer's likelihood of metastasizing to another part of the body.\n\nA growing awareness of cancer stem cells' role in cancer metastasis and recurrence and has been frustrated by the absence of technology that makes this knowledge useful to doctors and their patients. Up to now
column17: there has been no way of quickly and reliably separating and identifying the more dangerous tumor-causing cells from a biopsy.\n\nThe new device
column18: which was developed at Methodist
column19: successfully enriched tumor-causing cells from a mixture of cancer cells. It is called the Mechanical Separation Chip
column20: or MS-Chip. Cells separated by the device can be easily collected and studied. The current standard for cell separation
column21: flow cytometry
column22: is relatively slow and relies on cell surface biomarkers.\n\nOur microfluidics cell separation via MS-Chip provides a high throughput method that can particularly sort cells to different levels of stiffness
column23: which opens a new avenue to study stiffness related cellular and molecular biology
column24: Qin said. Downstream molecular analysis
column25: including genomic and proteomic profiling of the cell subtypes
column26: provides an approach to identifying new biomarkers relevant to cancer stem cells and cancer metastasis.\n\nRight now
column27: each MS-Chip costs about $10 to produce.\n\nIf massively produced
column28: MS-Chip cost could be at the level of one dollar per chip
column29: Qin said. Running a mechanical cell separation will be even less expensive than flow cytometry cell sorting.	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 22:28:41

(AP) -- The World Health Organization says a study has shown that babies with HIV could die if given a standard tuberculosis vaccine.

WHO says a three-year study in South Africa found babies born with HIV had a higher risk of contracting a deadly form of TB if given the widely used BCG vaccine.

The study recommends not vaccinating babies with HIV and delaying vaccination for those babies whose HIV status is unknown.

The study was published Wednesday in the journal Bulletin of the World Health Organization.

The first complete update in five years of the U. S. guidelines for preventing and treating HIV-associated opportunistic infections has been released by the National Institutes of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in cooperation with the HIV Medicine Association of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA).\n\nThe new Guidelines for Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in HIV-Infected Adults and Adolescents apply state-of-the-art science and medicine to 29 infectious diseases of concern. More than 140 medical experts contributed their knowledge to this edition of the guidelines
column10: these infections continue to threaten the health of many people infected with HIV
column11: says John T. Brooks
column12: M. D.
column13: co-author of the guidelines and leader of the HIV Clinical Epidemiology Team in CDC's Division of HIV/AIDS Prevention. It is critical that health care providers
column14: especially newer clinicians who may have less experience with opportunistic infections
column15: remain able to recognize the signs and symptoms of these infections and know how to provide the most effective preventive care and treatment.\n\nThe new guidelines combine what were previously two separate publications
column16:
one for the prevention of opportunistic infections (last published in 2002) and one for their treatment (first published in 2004).

Major changes to the guidelines include

* Emphasis on the important role of effective antiretroviral therapy in augmenting immune function
column17: which is pivotal to preventing and managing opportunistic infections\n\n* Information on the diagnosis and management of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome
column18: a condition in which the immune system begins to recover
column19:
but then responds to a previously acquired opportunistic infection with an overwhelming inflammatory response that worsens the symptoms of infection

* Information on the prevention and treatment of hepatitis B and C infections

* Information on interferon-gamma release assays for the detection of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

* Updated information on interactions between antiretroviral drugs and drugs used to treat opportunistic infections

* A new section on malaria and other tropical diseases that may become opportunistic infections in HIV-infected immigrants to the United States and in HIV-infected American travelers

HIV-associated opportunistic infections in the United States often occur in people who are unaware that they have HIV; in such cases
column20: the opportunistic infection may be the first sign of late-stage HIV disease. HIV-associated opportunistic infections also tend to occur among Americans who are aware of their HIV infection but are not receiving treatment for it
column21: who do not or cannot take antiretroviral therapy
column22: who take antiretroviral therapy but fail to benefit from it
column23: or who do not receive needed preventive care for an opportunistic infection.\n\nA draft of the new guidelines was released in June 2008 for public comment
column24: and an early edition of the new guidelines was published online on March 24. The finalized new Guidelines for Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections in HIV-Infected Adults and Adolescents are accessible at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr5804.pdf and http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5804a1.htm. These guidelines
column25: as well as all federal HIV prevention and treatment guidelines
column26: can be found on the AIDSInfo Web site at http://www.aidsinfo.nih.gov/Guidelines/Default.aspx?MenuItem=Guidelines.\n\nA final draft of the corresponding pediatric version of these guidelines
column27: Guidelines for the Prevention and Treatment of Opportunistic Infections among HIV-Exposed and HIV-Infected Children
column28: is under review and will be published later this year.	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 22:28:15

column16: when some  of that stuff can come back and impact you
column17: ” Taylor said.\n\nAlthough Taylor has been able to get treatment for PTSD
column18: thousands of  other veterans have been rejected. Until recently
column19: in order to get PTSD  treatment
column20: veterans needed to have documented proof of their  “stressors”—incidents
column21:
which would make them eligible.

The policy was only changed just this week.

During his July 10 weekly address
column22: President Barack Obama announced that  the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) will no longer require a  confirmed stressor in order for veterans to be diagnosed with PTSD.\n\nThe decision will now be on VA psychiatrists and psychologists
column23: who will  determine if a veteran’s experience supports a PTSD diagnosis
column24: and  whether the veteran’s symptoms result from the incidents.\n\nObama said that the practice of requiring veterans to give evidence of  the incident which caused their PTSD “... has kept the vast majority of  those with PTSD who served in noncombat roles
column25: but who still waged war
column26: from getting the care they need.”\n\nTaylor agrees
column27:
and shared his belief that the new policy is “going to be  a benefit to a lot of veterans who have had difficulty getting help  with PTSD.”

Roadblocks to Treatment

For some occupations
column28: stressors were a given. As a scout sniper
column29: “I have  plenty of documentation of stressors
column30: ” said Taylor.\n\nHe added that others—such as gunners on choppers—also had an easy time  proving their stressors. While leaving a hot landing zone
column31: and firing at  the enemy
column32: “They’d see their machine guns cut them down
column33: and then they  see the wounded and the maimed getting on the choppers
column34: ” said Taylor.\n\nFor others
column35: it hasn’t been so easy. Military doctors and nurses are  among those who have traditionally had trouble getting treatment.\n\nTaylor said he knew a man in the Navy who was on a helicopter near a  ship during Vietnam. The helicopter malfunctioned and crashed into the  ocean. He was the only survivor
column36: and was never eligible for PTSD  treatment since he was not in a combat zone.\n\nEven for those who saw combat
column37: being diagnosed wasn’t always easy. The  need to provide evidence of a stressor is sometimes a block even for  veterans who were in combat.\n\n“Those details may be forever burned into our minds
column38: but we often don’t  come away with hard copy proof of what occurred
column39: ” said Tammy Duckworth
column40: assistant secretary for public and intergovernmental affairs at the  Department of Veterans Affairs
column41: in a July 12 post on the White House  blog.\n\n“The previous arrangement is neither fair
column42: nor sustainable
column43: ” Duckworth  said. “This is especially true in the current wars in Iraq and  Afghanistan where there are no static front lines and the combat zone is  everywhere.”\n\nEven with the new standards in place
column44: however
column45: Taylor shared that  veterans may still face problems getting treatment—not from any  government body
column46: but rather from themselves.\n\n“One thing that I think everybody needs to understand—families
column47: relatives
column48: and the returning veterans—is you cannot go through something  like that and not be affected by it
column49: ” said Taylor. “That’s normal
column50: and  they tend to think that after they come back
column51: that there’s something  wrong with them if they’re affected by it.”\n\n“What we’re really afraid of is how we will be judged if we do talk  about it
column52: ” said Taylor.\n\nJoshua Philipp is an award-winning investigative reporter with The Epoch Times and host of EpochTV's Crossroads program. He is a recognized expert on unrestricted warfare
column53: asymmetrical hybrid warfare
column54: subversion
column55: and historical perspectives on today’s issues. His 10-plus years of research and investigations on the Chinese Communist Party
column56: subversion
column57: and related topics give him unique insight into the global threat and political landscape.How AI Girlfriends Could Mark the End of Relationships\n\nCopyright © 2000 - 2024 The Epoch Times Association Inc. All Rights Reserved.	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 23:26:54

Leaders in the Orthodox Jewish community are outraged by the apparent double standard exhibited by New York City authorities in the enforcement of lockdown measures.

They say Mayor Bill de Blasio has singled out the Jewish community as part of his effort to stop the spread of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) virus.

The double standard came into full focus on June 13
column10: Jewish kids playing on a playground
column11: who are at extremely low risk from this virus
column12: are at the same time being singled out.”\n\nThe “trans black lives” rally in Brooklyn was the latest in a series of protests and riots that swept the country in the wake of the police-custody death in Minneapolis of George Floyd. De Blasio spoke at one of the protests
column13: facing a crowd not practicing the social distancing guidelines and not wearing a mask himself.\n\n“I think the problem starts out when government officials make rules
column14: and then decide to make an exception to their own rules and join in on this exception
column15: ” Yossi Gestetner
column16: co-founder of the Orthodox Jewish Public Affairs Council
column17: told The Epoch Times.\n\n“If you set policy and then you make an exception to the rules
column18: on your own choice
column19:
you’re a dictator. And that’s not how freedom and liberties work in the United States.”

Gestetner noted that African Americans are statistically more vulnerable to adverse outcomes from the CCP virus. Yet the city’s leaders allowed a mass protest without the familiar reminders about social distancing and wearing masks.

“Why are you subjecting a minority community to an outbreak in the name of helping the same community? It’s diabolical
column20: ” Gestetner said.\n\nRabbi Joseph Potasnik
column21: executive vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis
column22: told The Epoch Times that his organization is actively consulting with several prominent epidemiologists about the precautions needed to reopen houses of worship. The scientists the board spoke to all concur that New York’s limitations on congregations are reasonable and necessary.\n\n“You don’t have any disagreement amongst the health professionals
column23: that we shouldn’t be lenient when it comes to opening these houses of worship
column24: ” Posatnik said. “I understand the stringency
column25: I just don’t understand why we’re not enforcing that kind of standard on protesters.”	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 20:25:09
