MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Minnesota Vikings star running back Adrian Peterson’s booking on a child abuse charge Saturday has created another crisis for the embattled NFL
column10: one of the NFL’s most popular players and widely considered one of the best running backs to ever play
column11: flew from Minnesota to Houston in the early morning hours after authorities indicted him on Friday evening. He has a home in both locations.\n\nThe Vikings almost immediately decided to deactivate him for Sunday’s game against the New England Patriots
column12: and NFL spokesman Brian McCarthy said on Saturday that Peterson’s case “will be reviewed under the NFL’s personal conduct policy.”\n\nThe situation comes as the NFL proceeds with a self-commissioned investigation by a former FBI director into how it handled the case of Ray Rice
column13: who knocked his then-fiancee unconscious in an Atlantic City elevator. Rice was released Monday from the Baltimore Ravens after a video surfaced that showed the violence. The NFL said it hadn’t seen the video before then
column14: but a law enforcement source told the AP it was sent to a league executive’s office in April and provided a voice mail confirming it was received.\n\nUnlike Rice’s situation
column15: Peterson’s case is complicated by his stance that he meant his son no harm but rather was applying the same discipline he experienced growing up.\n\n“Adrian is a loving father who used his judgment as a parent to discipline his son. He used the same kind of discipline with his child that he experienced as a child growing up in East Texas
column16: ” Peterson’s attorney
column17: Rusty Hardin
column18: said.\n\nSteve Eudey
column19: who coached Peterson as a young boy in Palestine
column20: Texas
column21: and has remained a family friend
column22: said he has heard stories from Peterson about his father Nelson “being a firm disciplinarian.”\n\n“Some of the things his dad did to him was to make him tough
column23: ” Eudey told The Associated Press.\n\nEudey said he had yet to speak to Peterson since his arrest
column24: but said his actions were consistent with the type of upbringing he had.\n\n“I will go to my grave defending Adrian
column25: but at the same time you can’t harm a child
column26: either
column27: ” Eudey said. “I know that was never his intent.”\n\nGrant
column28: the Texas prosecutor
column29: said the grand jury felt the charge was warranted after spending several weeks reviewing “lots of evidence.”\n\nIt’s not unusual for people subjected to physical discipline as children to use corporal punishment against their own children
column30: experts say
column31: and courts will sometimes consider that as a mitigating factor when sentencing an abuser. Peterson faces up to two years in prison and a $10
column32:
000 fine if found guilty.

News of Peterson’s charges led several prominent athletes to tweet about their experiences with corporal punishment when they were children.

“Am I the only one that got hit with a switch? I had to go outside and pick my own switch. It taught values
column33: respect (and) accountability
column34: ” former NBA star Tracy McGrady said. But he later qualified those remarks
column35: tweeting
column36: “Disciplining a child is vital. Of course any early physical punishment should be within reason
column37: not overboard
column38: and inside certain boundaries.”\n\nWhile the legal process plays out
column39: the NFL is facing a potential test case for the tougher penalties it declared last month for players involved with domestic violence.\n\nCommissioner Roger Goodell announced an initial offense will draw a six-week suspension without pay
column40: though “more severe discipline will be imposed if there are aggravating circumstances such as the presence or use of a weapon
column41: choking
column42: repeated striking
column43:
or when the act is committed against a pregnant woman or in the presence of a child.”

It is not clear if Peterson’s case will invoke those penalties.

Corporal punishment is legal in Texas
column44: and the law spells out that non-deadly force against a child by a parent or guardian is permissible.\n\nBut the punishment is abusive if it causes injury. While a blow that causes a red mark that fades in an hour is not likely to be judged abusive
column45: a blow that leaves a bruise
column46: welt
column47: or swelling
column48: or requires medical attention
column49: could be judged abusive. The child’s injuries will likely be under scrutiny as the case proceeds.\n\nThe guidelines also say while spanking with the bare
column50: open hand is least likely to be abusive
column51:
use of an instrument “is cause for concern.”

The Vikings jumped ahead of the NFL and the legal system by shelving Peterson for the game Sunday. Two other teams — Carolina and San Francisco — have taken heat for allowing players involved in alleged recent domestic violence incidents to continue to play.

The team — and the league — will likely face scrutiny as they decide whether Peterson returns to the field as the legal process plays out. As of Saturday
column52: no decision had been made about his outlook this season
column53: and no court date had been set in Texas.	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 20:23:12

Recovery in three months was similar for independent ADL and TUGWT.\n\nThese findings suggest that recovery after radical cystectomy takes three to six months and recovery in some domains may be quicker after RARC

Across Connecticut
column10: the antibodies from the plasma should help patients who are still sick to fight back against the disease.\n\nThe treatment is still experimental
column11: but Dr. Ajay Kumar
column12: the chief clinical officer at Hartford HealthCare
column13: said this week that a number of patients have shown improvement after convalescent plasma transfusions.\n\nMost patients are making good progress. Not all
column14: unfortunately
column15: but most are
column16: Kumar said. Drawing any conclusion from the earlier data would be premature ... but we are hopeful at this time.\n\nWhen Olson developed a fever in mid- to late-March
column17: it was the beginning of a coronavirus saga that would last for weeks.\n\nShe said the fever itself lasted 8 days
column18: and she spent a couple of weeks mostly in bed. But even after her other symptoms had ebbed
column19: Olson felt a deep fatigue for a total of more than a month.\n\nStairs would kill me
column20: Olson said. Doing a load of laundry would send me back to bed for the rest of the day.\n\nBut as she slowly recovered at home
column21: Olson was developing a super power.\n\nOn April 19
column22: she went to the American Red Cross in Farmington to donate blood plasma. She was hooked up to an apheresis machine
column23: which took blood through a needle in one of her arms
column24: pumped it through a machine to separate and remove the plasma and then pumped the remaining blood components back into her other arm.\n\nThe process took about an hour and a half
column25: Olson said
column26:
and it left her a bit woozy and lightheaded.

Other plasma donors say they have been affected by the donation process.

Chris Madison
column27: a 29-year-old programmer at Hartford Hospital
column28: said he didn't feel any weakness after an hour-long apherisis session at the American Red Cross in Westerly.\n\nAfter recovering from a relatively mild case of COVID-19
column29: Madison said he was happy that he could help out in some way
column30: particularly because many of his family members are front-line health care workers.\n\nI've been kind of sidelined a little bit
column31: being more of a programmer and having COVID and being quarantined
column32: Madison said. So I was just kind of looking for any way I could give back and kind of help with the crisis.\n\nThe plasma donation process can be lengthy—recovered patients have to go through all of the paperwork and blood type testing of a normal blood donation
column33: and then they also have to test negative for COVID-19.\n\nAfter recovering from the coronaviurs
column34: President of Bristol Health Kurt Barwis is currently waiting for his post-recovery test result so that he can donate plasma to Trinity Health's clinical trial. Even before his first plasma donation
column35: he's already decided that he'll donate plasma a second time.\n\nBarwis said he's heard that convalescent plasma can help severely ill patients
column36: which made donating a no-brainer.\n\nWe're still trying to figure out how to deal with this horrible disease
column37:
Barwis said. So why wouldn't we try to use the things that are working?

Some recovered hospital workers have hit roadblocks in the donation process.

Andrew Kemerly
column38: a first-year surgery resident at UConn Health
column39: tested positive for COVID-19 in mid-March. Right off the bat
column40: he asked to be notified if he could donate plasma.\n\nWhen I first tested
column41: I told them
column42: Please tell me if we get plasma donations set up
column43: ' Kemerly said.\n\nBut despite being symptom-free for weeks
column44: Kemerly's first post-recovery COVID-19 test came back inconclusive. His second post-recovery test came back positive. He's now waiting to once again get retested before donating plasma.\n\nAnother UConn Health employee had a similar experience. Amy Chmielewski
column45: who oversees the clinical curriculum for medical students
column46: had been symptom-free for two weeks when she was retested. Her test still came back positive.\n\nChmielewski was then retested again
column47: and this time it came back negative. She's hoping to be able to donate plasma soon. When the hospital reached out and asked if she wanted to donate
column48: Chmielewski said
column49:
she didn't even think of saying no.

Her moderate case of COVID-19 gave her a sense of the fear that the virus can bring—and she knows that the fear is magnified for patients who are severely ill.

Plasma is all we have at this point
column50: Chmielewski said. I was grateful for the opportunity to help.	P	2024-02-11 20:10:34	2024-02-11 22:18:52

column6: A federal judge has rejected an activist group’s request to prevent the Trump administration from asking 2020 Census respondents if they are U. S. citizens.\n\nIn recent decades
column10: which houses the Census Bureau
column11: announced the inclusion of a citizenship question in the upcoming census last year. One of the reasons given for adding the question
column12: which until the 1950s was a staple of the census
column13: was to help identify possible violations of the Voting Rights Act.\n\nMore recently
column14: the question has been included in the smaller
column15: more detailed study
column16: the Census Bureau’s annual American Community Survey
column17: which is sent to about 3.5 million households annually.\n\nBut last year
column18: Democratic politicians vehemently denounced putting the question in the census
column19:
accusing the Trump administration of having sinister ulterior motives.

Chair of the Democratic National Committee Tom Perez said the move was “a craven attack on our democracy and a transparent attempt to intimidate immigrant communities.” The census is not supposed to be “a political tool for Donald Trump to push his agenda and disempower Latinos and other people of color.”

column22: coupled women with children experienced a 4.4 point decline during lockdown
column23:
compared with only 1.2 point decline for coupled men with dependent children.

* No negative effect of lockdown was found for single mothers

* No evidence that lockdown effect was different for males in couples with or without dependent children

* Effects of lockdown on mental health were not driven by the most vulnerable populations (older adults living on their own
column24:
those with chronic physical or mental health conditions or those in the most disadvantaged socioeconomic circumstances)

* Mental health effects were greater among those with higher income

* No evidence of a lockdown effect on the mental health of adolescents aged 15 to 19 years (important to note that HILDA has previously shown a significant decline in the mental health of adolescents
column25: but this study shows the decline is not attributable to lockdowns\n\nWhile this study doesn't speak to the prolonged effects of lockdowns

column35: the term is commonly misused to describe people who like cleanliness or organisation - which underestimates the affect the condition can have on people with it.\n\nOne of the biggest misconceptions regarding OCD is that some people can be a 'little bit OCD'

column37: have feelings of anxiety or be superstitious

column40: has OCD as well as other mental health conditions and multiple sclerosis. She says another misconception is that people with OCD are only obsessive regarding cleaning
column41: but the condition can actually manifest in many different ways.\n\nI think the biggest misconception I know of is that all people with OCD are clean freaks. We do not all furiously clean our house or have an extreme fear of germs and wash our hands continuously
column42: she says.\n\nFor Wheeler
column43: OCD affects her home life and the way she eats
column44: as her food must be prepared in a certain order. If I lose something
column45: I spend hours looking for it
column46: staying awake until I find whatever it is - often keeping my husband awake while looking around in my bedroom for what it is
column47: she says.\n\nWhether someone develops OCD depends on a number of factors

column49: genetics or life events. Although it is a long term (chronic) and debilitating condition
column50: many people overcome OCD with treatment and support - or are able to reduce the impact it has on their lives.\n\nThere are many ways that a person can get treatment for OCD
column51: Shirley says. The most common would be to visit your GP in order to explain your symptoms
column52: before being referred to a specialist service such as a cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) therapist.\n\nWith talking therapy
column53: such as CBT

column58:
as well as a well-constructed relapse prevention programme for the person to follow once they finish therapy.

A therapy called exposure and response prevention can also be included as a part of CBT. This involves encouraging someone to face their fears and let obsessive thoughts happen without following them up with compulsions to 'fix' them.

Your doctor or a specialist may recommend taking certain medication
column59: as well as therapy.\n\nGetting advice

column10: mistake for an inconsequential viral infection. In fact

column12: it can lead to irreversible heart damage. Decades of research have been unable to pinpoint the cause of the disease
column13: although genetic studies show a heritable tendency to acquiring the disease.\n\nFindings of an international team of scientists - organized by Jane C. Burns
column14: MD
column15: professor of pediatrics and director of the Kawasaki Disease Research Center at the University of California
column16: San Diego School of Medicine and Rady Children's Hospital-San Diego – now support earlier evidence that KD cases are linked to large-scale wind currents that track from Asia to Japan and also traverse the North Pacific.\n\nThe study found that 40 percent more cases of Kawasaki disease in the Northern hemisphere occurred from January through March than from August through September – coinciding with high and low intensities of tropospheric winds. Previous studies showed that when winds blew from the northwest across Japan in a southeasterly direction
column17: the number of KD cases there increased. At the conclusion of the epidemics
column18: the wind had reversed direction and commenced blowing across Japan from the Pacific Ocean in a northwesterly direction. This same pattern was repeated from year to year.\n\nThe passage of these large-scale wind patterns across the Pacific was similarly associated with an increase in KD cases in San Diego
column19: California.\n\nThis study built and expanded upon earlier research investigating a possible influence from large-scale environmental factors
column20: (published by this scientific team in a November 2011 study in Nature Scientific Reports) by a team of researchers that also included two contributors to this study: Daniel R. Cayan
column21: Climate Atmospheric Science and Physical Oceanography (CASPO) at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla
column22: and Xavier Rodó of the Institut Català de Ciències del Clima and the Institució Catalana de Recerca (IC3) in Barcelona
column23: Spain.\n\nOur data suggest a seasonal exposure to a KD agent that operates over large geographic regions and is concentrated during winter months in non-tropical regions of the Northern hemisphere
column24: Burns said.\n\nDatasets were much sparser in the tropics and the Southern hemisphere
column25: but showed a maximum incidence in May through June
column26: with approximately 30 percent of the cases occurring in that time period; however
column27: the pattern was not considered statistically significant.\n\nDuring winter months
column28: there are stronger seasonal winds across the Northern hemisphere
column29: which could lead to increased transport of the suspected KD agent
column30: said Burns. This may explain
column31: in part
column32: the consistency in the seasonal nature of Kawasaki disease that we observe in our pediatric patients.\n\nWhile there is no diagnostic test
column33: signs of KD include prolonged fever associated with rash
column34: red eyes
column35: mouth
column36: lips and tongue
column37: and swollen hands and feet with peeling skin. The disease causes damage to the coronary arteries in a quarter of untreated children and may lead to serious heart problems in early adulthood. The aneurysm rate for Kawasaki disease is 5 percent
column38: and the death rate is 0.1 percent.\n\nWhile seasonality of the disease has been noted in many regions – particularly in Japan
column39: the country of highest incidence for KD – the search for factors that might contribute to epidemics and fluctuations in KD occurrence has been elusive. A study of KD cases in Japan since 1970 showed three dramatic nationwide epidemics
column40: each lasting several months and peaking in April 1979 (6
column41: 700 cases)
column43: 100 cases) and March 1986 (14
column44: 700 cases). These three peaks represent the largest KD epidemic events ever recorded in the world.\n\nPrevious epidemiological investigations suggest that the causative agent for KD is widely distributed in the environment
column45: that there is no person-to-person transmission and that genetic susceptibility plays a part in at least some of the disease variation across different ethnic and racial groups. Japan continues to be the country of highest incidence
column46: but seasonality of the disease has been documented in Hawaii and San Diego as well.\n\nThe scientists report that this recent comprehensive analysis to detect seasonal cycles of KD cases from around the world could be significant in efforts to isolate the cause of this devastating childhood disease. NEW YORK—The New Year’s Ball drop in New York City is going green.

People can power up the world famous New Year’s Eve ball drop by pedaling a stationary bike  at 7th Avenue and 42nd Street starting Saturday. Participants will be rewarded with a free Citi Bike day pass for their efforts.

Six bikes will be set up to collect kinetic energy from pedaling to batteries. The energy will then be transferred to the city’s grid to offset the power use for the ball drop.

“Citi Bikes have energized New York City

THE ASSOCIATED PRESS UK update: Jury mulls verdicts at UK phone hacking trial

LONDON (AP) — The jury at Britain’s phone hacking trial has retired to consider verdicts against seven defendants charged with wrongdoing at Rupert Murdoch’s British tabloids. The panel of eight women and three men will decide whether to convict or acquit ex-News of the World editors Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson
column19: and five others.The trial began in October and ran for 130 days. It was spawned by revelations that the tabloid had eavesdropped on the voicemails of celebrities

column21: which include phone hacking

Antithyroid medicines are used to treat an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Carbimazole is the most commonly used medicine. You may require careful monitoring to get the right levels of these medicines for you. Most of the side-effects experienced are minor. However
column10:
or it may be used in a thyrotoxic crisis. Propylthiouracil is also used for an overactive thyroid gland in pregnancy. Your doctor will advise you on which is the most suitable for you.

Getting the right balance of thyroid hormone in your blood can take time. Doctors have two main methods of trying to get the balance right.

The first involves taking an initial high dose of carbimazole to reduce the amount of thyroxine in your blood. This dose is taken until the hormone levels in your blood have stabilised
column11: usually about four to eight weeks later.\n\nBecause your body needs a certain amount of thyroxine to function properly
column12: the high dose is then slowly decreased. Usually
column13:
your hormone levels will be checked by a blood test every month or so.

The dose of medicine you are taking will be changed depending upon the results of your thyroid hormone levels. The aim of this treatment is to keep you on the lowest level of antithyroid medicine necessary. This treatment method is called 'titration'.

It can be difficult for a doctor to judge just the right dose of carbimazole to give in each case. Too much treatment may make the thyroxine level go too low. Not enough treatment means the level remains higher than normal. This is the reason for the regular blood tests and careful monitoring.

The second option is to deliberately take a high dose of carbimazole each day. This stops the thyroid gland making any thyroxine. Your doctor can then prescribe a daily dose of thyroxine to keep the blood level of thyroxine normal. This 'over-treatment' coupled with taking replacement thyroxine is called 'block and replace' and is a popular option.

It is generally thought that the 'block and replace' method results in better control of thyroid hormone levels. However
column14:
the risk of experiencing an adverse effect from the higher dose of antithyroid medicine may be higher.

These medicines should have some effect on your symptoms around 10 to 14 days after treatment starts. Thyroid hormone levels are usually stabilised within four to eight weeks of taking the medication.

This may vary depending on the way in which you take your medicines. Hyperthyroidism is what is known as a relapsing-remitting illness. This means that the symptoms of the condition may get better (remit) or get worse (relapse).

Medical evidence suggests that about half of people treated by the titration method will get better (achieve remission) after 18 to 24 months of treatment. However
column15:
about half of those treated by the 'block and replace' method will achieve remission within six months of treatment.

Your doctor will advise you on which treatment option may be suitable for you. 'Block and replace' therapy is not suitable in pregnancy.

As mentioned before
column16: having an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) is generally a relapsing-remitting illness
column17:
which means symptoms may return after treatment.

If you feel unwell following treatment you should return to your doctor. Your GP should be able to advise you on the type of symptoms to look out for.

It is usually advisable to treat an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Untreated hyperthyroidism can cause significant problems with your heart and other organs. It may also increase your risk of complications should you become pregnant. However
column18: in many cases there are other treatment options. That is
column19:
radioactive iodine or surgery may be suitable options.

See the separate leaflet called Overactive Thyroid Gland (Hyperthyroidism) for details of these other treatment options.

Most people who take antithyroid medicines do not experience any side-effects. The side-effects that most commonly occur are:

The above side-effects are usually not serious and often go
column20: even if you continue with the medication.\n\nA rare but serious side-effect is an effect on the bone marrow which produces red blood cells
column21: white blood cells and platelets. Antithyroid drug therapy can reduce the numbers of these cells being produced. The lower number of red blood cells causes anaemia. The effect on white blood cells (or neutrophils) is called agranulocytosis. The drastically reduced number of white blood cells in your body may mean you are less able to fight off infection. The reduced number of platelets may make you more likely to bleed. Therefore
column22: if you experience any of these whilst on the medicine
column23: you must stop taking it and report this to your doctor immediately
column25: a mild rash is a common side-effect. The rash associated with this rare but serious effect on blood-making cells is different. Therefore
column26: when taking an antithyroid medicine
column27: always report a rash to a doctor who can then decide if it is a common and minor problem or the more serious rash.\n\nYou cannot buy these medicines. They are only available from your chemist
column28: with a doctor's prescription
column29: and are usually started by a specialist doctor.\n\nPregnant women or those planning a baby should seek the advice of their GP
column30:
as these medicines are able to cross the placenta. The placenta is the organ that provides nourishment and oxygen to a baby in the womb (uterus). Antithyroid medicines may not be suitable for people with some forms of liver or kidney disease.

A full list of people who should not take antithyroid medicines is included with the information leaflet that comes with your medicine. Read this to be sure you are safe to take it.

These medicines sometimes react with other medicines that you may take. So
column31: make sure your doctor knows of any other medicines that you are taking
column32: including ones that you have bought rather than been prescribed.\n\nWhen you look up this condition on the internet
column33: there will be some kind of 'natural remedy' that promises a great cure without all those 'nasty medicines' that doctors prescribe.\n\nBe careful: an overactive thyroid gland is a potentially serious condition
column34: particularly for your heart. It's best to get an opinion from a qualified doctor (MBChB or MBBS)
column35: preferably one who is impartial and paid by a state-funded system like the NHS
column36: before trying any homeopathic treatments.\n\nWhen someone has an underactive thyroid gland
column37: they are given a medicine to boost their levels of thyroxine. This medicine is called levothyroxine. Sometimes this can help the person lose weight
column38: if their underactive thyroid gland has caused them to put on weight. See the separate leaflet called Underactive Thyroid Gland (Hypothyroidism).\n\nUnfortunately
column39: as you can imagine
column40:
some unscrupulous people get hold of levothyroxine and then try to sell it as a 'weight loss' cure.

Be careful: it's true that taking lots of levothyroxine could make you lose weight but it will also be very harmful to your body. It will turn you into having an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) with all of the bad effects of that condition that have been discussed in this leaflet.

The best and healthiest way to lose weight is to eat healthily and be active. See the separate leaflet called Weight Loss (Weight Reduction) for help on losing weight.	P	2024-02-11 19:10:33	2024-02-11 20:39:11

Researchers have found that digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) has improved breast cancer screening performance in community practice and identifies more invasive cancers
column10: DBT was rapidly adopted in the U.S. As of September 2022
column11: 84% of all mammography screening facilities in the U.S. had DBT units.\n\nBreast cancer mortality reduction from routine screening is contingent upon radiologists' interpretive performance. Since the Mammography Quality Standards Act was enacted in 1992
column12: screening facilities and interpreting radiologists have been required to meet minimum quality standards. Beginning in 2006
column13: the Breast Cancer Surveillance Consortium (BCSC) has published screening performance benchmarks. The BCSC is a collaborative network of breast imaging registries conducting research to assess and improve the delivery and quality of breast cancer screening and related patient outcomes.\n\nTo establish performance benchmarks for DBT screening and evaluate performance trends over time in U. S. community practices
column14: the research team collected DBT screening exams from five BCSC registries between 2011 and 2018.\n\nCompared to BCSC digital mammography screening exams from the same time period and previously published BCSC and National Mammography Database performance benchmarks

column16: which were similar to concurrent and prior digital mammography performance measures.\n\nRadiologists appear to perform better with digital breast tomosynthesis and have higher accuracy on screening 3D mammograms than 2D mammograms across U. S. practices
